questions.text: A 68-year-old woman was hospitalized for three days for left leg cellulitis. She was treated with clindamycin. Two days after her discharge, abdominal pain, and watery diarrhea. Lab results showed leukocytes 17,500/mm3, elevated ESR and CRP. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Clostridioides difficile

Explanation:

The patient’s symptoms—abdominal pain, watery diarrhea, elevated leukocytes, ESR, and CRP—are consistent with Clostridioides difficile infection, commonly referred to as C. difficile. This infection is often associated with antibiotic use, particularly clindamycin, which can disrupt the normal gut flora and allow for the overgrowth of C. difficile. The bacteria produce toxins that can cause colitis (inflammation of the colon), leading to symptoms such as diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever.

Prolonged antibiotic use disrupts the normal gut flora, creating an environment conducive to Clostridioides difficile colonization and infection. This patient must have been put on multiple courses of broad-spectrum antibiotics for surgical prophylaxis as well as post-surgery. This is a well-established risk factor for developing pseudomembranous colitis.

 

Pseudomembranous colitis, a severe manifestation of C. difficile infection (CDI), involves:

  • Colon inflammation
  • Formation of whitish-yellow plaques on the colonic mucosa.
    • Sized - 1-2mm, or covering extensive areas of the colon.
    • These plaques consist of necrotic leukocytes.
      • Fibrin,
      • Mucus, and
      • Cellular debris
  • Toxins A (enterotoxin) and B (cytotoxin) are the main toxins produced by C. difficile. They disrupt the actin cytoskeleton by glycosylating GTP-binding proteins, which leads to cell shape loss, reduced cell adhesion, and a weakened epithelial barrier. This disruption is a key factor in the pathogenicity of C. difficile.

Diagnosis

1. Colonoscopy
  • Examination of the colon whitish-yellow plaques on the colonic mucosa known as microabscesses.
  • Although it is highly specific, it is not as sensitive as ELISA, hence it is not considered the Gold standard for diagnosis.

2. Culture
  • Stool samples cultured on selective media to identify C. difficile; less sensitive than toxin detection.

3. Toxin Detection
  • ELISA: Detects toxins A and/or B in stool samples, the gold standard.
  • Cell Culture: Toxins produce characteristic effects on Hep-2 or human diploid cell cultures, neutralized by C. sordellii antitoxin.

4. Molecular Methods
  • PCR: Detects genes coding for toxins A and B in stool samples.

5. Histopathology
  • This can be performed with hematoxylin and eosin stains
  • Highly specific but low sensitivity

Treatment

Antibiotic Discontinuation
  • Stop the antibiotic suspected of contributing to the infection.

Antibiotic Therapy
  • Oral vancomycin or metronidazole.
  • Severe cases: Combination of oral vancomycin, intravenous metronidazole, and rectal vancomycin enemas.

Prevention

Antibiotic Stewardship
  • Limit the use of broad-spectrum antibiotics like clindamycin, ampicillin, and fluoroquinolones; prevent disruption of normal gut flora.

Infection Control Measures
  • Meticulous hand hygiene and contact precautions in healthcare settings.

Recent Treatment Option

Fecal Transplants
  • Replenishing gut flora with donated faeces from screened healthy donor

questions.text: A farmer presents with a lesion on his arm after working with cattle on his farm. Gram staining of a sample from the lesion reveals gram-positive rods with square ends and central spores. What is the most likely organism causing this lesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Bacillus anthracis

Explanation:

The description of gram-positive rods with square ends and central spores is a hallmark of Bacillus anthracis, the causative agent of anthrax. Anthrax is a zoonotic infection that is typically contracted by handling infected animals or animal products, which is consistent with the farmer’s exposure to cattle. The cutaneous form of anthrax presents with a painless ulcer that forms a characteristic black eschar, which is highly suggestive of Bacillus anthracis infection.

questions.text: A patient with meningitis was examined. His CSF shows lymphocytosis, decreased glucose, and increased protein. What is the etiological agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Mycobacterium tuberculosis

Explanation: The CSF (cerebrospinal fluid) findings of lymphocytosis, decreased glucose, and increased protein are characteristic of tuberculous meningitis, which is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB).

Tuberculous Meningitis

  • Tuberculous meningitis presents with a subacute course of headaches, mental changes, and fever over weeks, with CSF findings of lymphocyte predominance, elevated protein, and low glucose. Cobweb coagulum seen in CSF.

Cobweb coagulum

  • Cranial nerve palsies and hydrocephalus can occur.
  • AFB smear is often negative, and diagnosis may rely on culture or Xpert MTB/RIF assay.

TB Meningitis

Pathophysiology
  • Tuberculous Meningitis results from hematogenous spread of primary or postprimary TB or rupture of a subependymal tubercle into the subarachnoid space.

Onset

Evolves over 1–2 weeks, slower than bacterial meningitis.

Symptoms
  • Early Symptoms
    • Headache, mild mental changes, low-grade fever, malaise, anorexia, irritability over several weeks.
  • Advanced Symptoms
    • Severe headache, confusion, lethargy, altered sensorium, neck rigidity, cranial nerve palsies (especially ocular). Can progress to coma, hydrocephalus, and intracranial hypertension.

Lumbar Puncture Findings (CSF)
  • High leukocyte count (up to 1000/μL), typically lymphocyte predominance
  • Protein: 1–8 g/L (100–800 mg/dL)
  • Low glucose concentration
  • AFB is rarely seen; repeated lumbar punctures increase yield.
  • CSF culture diagnostic in up to 80% (gold standard).

Xpert MTB/RIF Assay
  • Sensitivity up to 80%.
  • A negative result does not exclude TB.

Imaging
  • CT, MRI: Shows hydrocephalus and enhancement of basal cisterns or ependyma.

Basal cistern enhancement

  • In >50% of cases, old pulmonary lesions or military pattern on CXR.

Treatment

Immediate treatment with positive Xpert MTB/RIF.

  • Chemotherapy is effective but neurologic sequelae occur in 25% of cases, especially with delayed diagnosis.
  • Glucocorticoid Therapy
    • Dexamethasone reduces mortality and severe disability but may not prevent neurological sequelae.
    • Regimen: 0.4 mg/kg/day IV, tapering weekly, followed by oral tapering. WHO recommends tapering over 6–8 weeks.

Lymphocytosis (Option A): The presence of lymphocytes in the CSF suggests a chronic infection or inflammation, which is typical of tuberculous meningitis.

Decreased glucose (Option B): Low glucose levels in the CSF are a hallmark of tuberculous meningitis (as well as other forms of bacterial meningitis), as the bacteria consume glucose. This is often seen in tuberculosis-related infections.

Increased protein (Option C): Elevated protein levels in the CSF are also consistent with tuberculous meningitis, which causes an inflammatory response and protein leakage into the CSF.

questions.text: A patient has a fever, rash, and eschar formation due to a mite bite. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Scrub typhus

Explanation:Scrub typhus is caused by the bacterium Orientia tsutsugamushi and is transmitted through the bite of an infected mite (specifically the chigger mite). The hallmark features of scrub typhus include fever, rash, and eschar formation at the site of the mite bite. The eschar is a necrotic ulcer with a characteristic black center, often seen in patients with scrub typhus.

  • Rash involving the palms and soles are typically seen in the following diseases:
    • Rocky Mountain spotted fever (Rickettsia rickettsii)
    • Hand-foot-mouth disease (CoxSackie A virus)
    • Secondary syphilis

Scrub typhus

Causative agent

Orientia tsutsugamushi - It differs from Rickettsia both genetically and by its cell wall composition i.e. it lacks lipopolysaccharide layer.

Vector

Chiggers (larvae of trombiculid mite)

Pathophysiology
  • Scrub typhus is so named because it occurs in scrub vegetation i.e. low-lying trees and bushes.
  • The bite of infected trombiculid mites transmits it.
  • Among all stages of mite, the larvae (called chiggers) are the only stage that feed on humans. Hence, scrub typhus is also called chiggerosis.
  • Mites can maintain the organisms through transovarial transmission.
  • Orientia tsutsugamushi infects mononuclear cells but still produces fever and rash.

Clinical features

  • The classic presentation of scrub typhus consists of triad of an eschar (at the site of bite), regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash sparing palms and soles.
  • Non-specific manifestations may appear early such as fever, headache, myalgia, cough, and gastrointestinal symptoms.
  • Complications such as encephalitis and interstitial pneumonia may occur rarely in the late stage (due to vascular injury).

Investigations

  • The Weil-Felix test shows OX K+ only.

Treatment

  • Doxycycline is the drug choice.
  • Azithromycin is given alternatively and the drug of choice in children and pregnant women.

Anthrax (Option A): Anthrax is caused by Bacillus anthracis and typically presents with a papule that ulcerates, forming an eschar, but it does not typically present with a generalized rash or fever in the same way as scrub typhus. Anthrax is more common in individuals who handle animal products.

African tick typhus (Option C): This is caused by Rickettsia africae and transmitted by tick bites. It presents similarly to scrub typhus with fever and eschar, but scrub typhus is more common in regions like Asia, whereas African tick typhus is more common in sub-Saharan Africa.

Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF) (Option D): RMSF is caused by Rickettsia rickettsii and transmitted by tick bites. It typically presents with fever, rash, and eschar, but the rash in RMSF tends to start on the wrists and ankles and spreads centrally, unlike the rash seen in scrub typhus. It also doesn't commonly feature an eschar at the site of the tick bite.

Detects IgG antibodies

Distinguishes between IgM and IgG antibodies

questions.text: A patient presents with a history of watery diarrhea and vomiting. The pathogen exhibited darting motility. Which is the best selective media for the involved pathogen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) TCBS

Explanation:

  • Given the clinical presentation of watery diarrhea and vomiting, the most likely pathogen involved is Vibrio cholerae or another species of the Vibrio genus, which are known to cause gastroenteritis and are characterized by darting motility under the microscope.
  • TCBS agar is a selective culture medium specifically designed for isolating Vibrio species, including Vibrio cholerae. It allows for the growth of alkaline-tolerant bacteria and inhibits the growth of most other enteric bacteria.
  • Colonies of Vibrio cholerae typically appear as yellow on this medium due to sucrose fermentation, making this method highly specific for confirming the diagnosis.

Specimen Collection:

  • Preferred Specimen: Stool (mucus flakes)
  • Alternative: Rectal swab if stool is not available
  • Enrichment broth : selenite F broth and alkaline peptone water

Transport Media:

  • VR (Venkatraman Ramakrishnan) media - specific transport media for V. cholera
  • Cary-Blair medium

Microscopy:

  • Morphology: Comma or curved-shaped, reddish Gram-negative bacilli
  • Appearance: Fish-in-stream appearance
  • Motility: Demonstrated by dark field or phase contrast microscopy showing darting motility

Culture:

  • Culture Media and Colony Characteristics:
    • MacConkey Agar: Colorless colonies that may later turn pink due to late fermentation of lactose
    • Blood Agar: Green colonies indicating hemolysis
    • Nutrient Agar: Translucent, round discs with a bluish tinge under transmitted light
    • Gelatin Stab: Infundibuliform (funnel-shaped) or napiform (turnip-shaped) liquefaction

  • Thiosulfate-Citrate-Bile Salts-Sucrose (TCBS) Agar: (Option B)
    • Differentiates between sucrose fermenters (like Vibrio cholerae) and non-sucrose fermenters (such as Vibrio parahaemolyticus).
    • Vibrio cholerae produces yellow colonies due to sucrose fermentation.

  • Fermentation: Glucose and sucrose
  • Indole Test: Positive
  • Nitrate Reduction: Nitrates are reduced to nitrites
  • Cholera Red Reaction: Due to nitroso-indole formation
  • Catalase: Positive
  • Oxidase: Positive
  • String Test: A loopful of growth mixed with 0.5% deoxycholate results in string formation

  • Indirect Hemagglutination
  • Complement- Dependent Vibriocidal Antibody Test

  • Rehydration:
    • Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS)
    • Intravenous (IV) fluids
  • Antibiotics: Secondary treatment

Nutrient media (Option A): This is a general-purpose medium and is not selective, so it wouldn’t be the best choice for isolating Vibrio species.

Cetrimide agar (Option C): This medium is selective for Pseudomonas aeruginosa, not Vibrio species.

Potassium Tellurite Agar (Option D): This is typically used for isolating Corynebacterium diphtheriae, not for Vibrio.

questions.text: Which of the following is the mechanism of action of diphtheria toxin?

choices.text: ADP phosphorylation of EF-2 - Decreasing protein synthesis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) ADP phosphorylation of EF-2 - Decreasing protein synthesis

Explanation:

  • Diphtheria toxin is produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae and inhibits protein synthesis in host cells through the ADP-ribosylation of elongation factor 2 (EF-2). This modification prevents EF-2 from functioning properly in the process of translation, thereby halting protein synthesis. The result is cellular death, and this mechanism is primarily responsible for the tissue damage observed in diphtheria, particularly in the respiratory system.

Diphtheria Toxin:

Aspect

Details

Production and Structure
  • DT is a protein exotoxin produced by the toxigenic Corynebacterium diphtheriae.
  • Consists of two fragments(Bipartite), A and B, with a molecular weight of approximately 62,000 daltons.

Role of Lysogenic β-phage
  • The tox gene is carried by a lysogenic β-phage.
  • Only phage-infected strains produce toxin; nontoxigenic strains can become toxigenic if infected.
  • Corynebacterium diphtheriae remains localized at the infection site, with only the toxin entering circulation, causing toxaemia but not bacteremia.

Mechanism of Action
  • Fragment B binds host cell receptors, facilitating fragment A entry into the cytoplasm.
  • Fragment A catalyses ADP-ribosylation of EF-2, halting protein synthesis.

Potency
  • The lethal dose for a 250g guinea pig: is 0.0001 mg.
  • The estimated lethal dose for humans: 130 ng/kg body weight.

Systemic Effects
  • DT spreads via blood, causing myocarditis and neuritis.
  • Myocarditis is potentially fatal.

Factors Affecting Production
  • Influenced by environmental factors: alkaline pH (7.8-8.0), oxygen, and iron concentration in the growth medium.
  • High production with low iron availability (0.1 mg/l); iron addition inhibits production (0.5 mg/l).

Toxoid Formation
  • Treatment with formalin (0.2-0.4%), and incubation at 37°C for 4-6 weeks converts DT to toxoid.
  • Toxoid lacks toxicity but induces an immune response; used in vaccines.

Immunity
  • Immunity is primarily mediated by antitoxin antibodies neutralizing DT.

Incorrect Options:

Increasing cAMP (Option B): This is the mechanism of action for toxins like the cholera toxin or the pertussis toxin, not diphtheria toxin.

Increasing cGMP (Option C): This is typically seen in other bacterial toxins (e.g., E. coli enterotoxins), but not in diphtheria.

Decreasing 60s ribosome (Option D): While protein synthesis is affected by diphtheria toxin, it does not directly decrease the 60S ribosome, but rather modifies EF-2, which is necessary for the elongation step in protein synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not transmitted by the vector shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Orientia tsutsugamushi

Explanation:

Orientia tsutsugamushi causes scrub typhus and is transmitted by the bite of Leptotrombidium mites (chiggers).

Scrub typhus

Causative agent

Orientia tsutsugamushi - It differs from Rickettsia both genetically and by its cell wall composition i.e. it lacks lipopolysaccharide layer.

Vector

Chiggers (larvae of trombiculid mite)

Pathophysiology
  • Scrub typhus is so named because it occurs in areas of scrub vegetation i.e. low lying trees and bushes.
  • It is transmitted by the bite of infected trombiculid mites.
  • Among all stages of mite, the larvae (called chiggers) are the only stage that feed on humans. Hence, scrub typhus is also called chiggerosis.
  • Mites can maintain the organisms through transovarial transmission.
  • Orientia tsutsugamushi infects mononuclear cells but still produces fever and rash.

Clinical features

  • The classic presentation of scrub typhus consists of triad of an eschar (at the site of bite), regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash sparing palms and soles.
  • Non-specific manifestations may appear early such as fever, headache, myalgia, cough, and gastrointestinal symptoms.
  • Complications such as encephalitis and interstitial pneumonia may occur rarely in the late stage (due to vascular injury).

Investigations

The Weil-Felix test shows OX K+ only.

Treatment

  • Doxycycline is the drug choice.
  • Azithromycin is given alternatively and the drug of choice in children and pregnant women.

Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (Option B): This viral hemorrhagic fever is caused by the Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus (CCHFV) and is transmitted by Hyalomma ticks.

Babesiosis (Option C): Babesia species cause babesiosis, a malaria-like illness, and are transmitted by Ixodid (hard) ticks, primarily Ixodes scapularis (deer tick).

Ehrlichiosis (Option D): Ehrlichia species, responsible for human ehrlichiosis, are transmitted by Amblyomma americanum (Lone Star tick) and other tick species.

questions.text: The image below demonstrates the mechanism of action of a certain pathogen. Which of the following pathogens is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Streptococcus pyogenes

Explanation:

  • Streptococcus pyogenes produces streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxins (SPEs), which act as superantigens.
  • These exotoxins cause an exaggerated immune response by directly linking T-cell receptors to MHC class II molecules, leading to massive cytokine release.

Vibrio cholerae (Option A): Vibrio cholerae produces cholera toxin, which ADP-ribosylates the Gsα subunit of adenylate cyclase, leading to increased cAMP levels. This results in massive chloride and water secretion in the intestines, causing profuse watery diarrhea.

questions.text: An elderly male presents with meningitis, and the CSF sample is subjected to Gram staining and microscopy, as shown in the image. Which of the following characteristics is associated with the most likely organism?

choices.text: No motility at 22°C and motile at 37°C

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Motile at 22°C and non-motile at 37°C

Explanation:

  • The most likely causative organism in an elderly patient with meningitis is Listeria monocytogenes, a Gram-positive bacillus.
  • Listeria exhibits characteristic tumbling motility at 22°C due to peritrichous flagella but loses motility at 37°C as flagellar expression is downregulated in host environments.

questions.text: A farmer presents with fever and physical examination findings as seen in the image. His serum creatinine is 1.4 mg/dL, and platelet count is 88,000/mm³. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Scrub typhus

Explanation:

Scrub typhus, caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi and transmitted by Trombiculid mites (chiggers).

  • Characteristic eschar (necrotic ulcer with a black scab) is seen at the site of the mite bite.
  • Common in farmers and individuals exposed to rural, wooded, or grassy areas.
  • Other features include fever, thrombocytopenia, acute kidney injury (AKI), hepatosplenomegaly, and rash.

Causative agent

Orientia tsutsugamushi - It differs from Rickettsia both genetically and by its cell wall composition i.e. it lacks lipopolysaccharide layer.

Chiggers (larvae of trombiculid mite)

  • The classic presentation of scrub typhus consists of triad of an eschar (at the site of bite), regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash sparing palms and soles.

  • Complications such as encephalitis and interstitial pneumonia may occur rarely in the late stage (due to vascular injury).

The Weil-Felix test shows OX K+ only.

  • Doxycycline is the drug choice.
  • Azithromycin is given alternatively and the drug of choice in children and pregnant women.

Anthrax (Option B): Cutaneous anthrax presents with painless ulcers with black eschar but has extensive surrounding edema and is more commonly seen in individuals handling animal hides or wool.

Leptospirosis (Option C): Causes Weil’s disease with jaundice, renal failure, and hemorrhage, but does not present with an eschar. Common in farmers exposed to rodent-contaminated water.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms exhibits transcellular movement with the aid of actin filaments?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Listeria

Explanation:

Listeria shows tumbling type of motility at 25°C and non-motile at 37°C, which is known as differential motility.

It uses Actin Filaments for Intracellular Motility and Cell-to-Cell Spread .

  • It takes over the host actin cytoskeleton by expressing ActA, which polymerizes actin filaments and forms actin comet tails.
  • This propels the bacterium through the cytoplasm and into adjacent cells, allowing transcellular movement.
  • This mechanism helps evade immune detection and enables spread across the intestinal, placental, and blood-brain barriers.

Enteroinvasive E. coli (Option B): Does Not Use Actin-Based Motility

  • EIEC invades colonic epithelial cells but does not use actin filaments for movement.
  • Instead, it uses a type III secretion system (T3SS) for intracellular invasion.

Salmonella (Option C): Uses Actin for Invasion, Not Intracellular Motility

  • Salmonella uses actin cytoskeleton remodeling to enter host cells.
  • It employs Salmonella Pathogenicity Islands (SPI-1 and SPI-2) for invasion and intracellular survival.

questions.text: A sample from a patient was stained and examined under a microscope. Which of the following correctly identifies the organism and staining method used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Nocardia and acid-fast stain

Explanation:

  • Nocardia is a gram-positive, branching filamentous bacteria that is partially acid-fast due to the presence of mycolic acid in its cell wall.
  • It is best identified using modified acid-fast staining (Kinyoun or Ziehl-Neelsen stain), which helps differentiate it from Actinomyces (which is acid-fast negative).

 

Streptococcus and Gram Stain (Option B): Streptococcus is a gram-positive cocci and is best visualized using a Gram stain, not an acid-fast stain.

Cryptococcus and India Ink (Option C): Cryptococcus neoformans is a yeast with a polysaccharide capsule, best visualized using India ink stain, which highlights the clear halo around the yeast cells.

Coccidioidomycosis and PAS Stain (Option D): Coccidioides (a dimorphic fungus) is best visualized using Periodic Acid-Schiff (PAS) stain or Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) stain, but it does not appear as branching filamentous bacteria.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Diphtheria toxin

Explanation:

Diphtheria toxin (Produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae), ADP-ribosylates elongation factor-2 (EF-2), leading to inhibition of protein synthesis.

  • This results in cell death, leading to pseudomembrane formation in the pharynx and systemic complications like myocarditis and neuropathy.

 

Diphtheria Toxin

Production and Structure
  • DT is a protein exotoxin produced by the toxigenic Corynebacterium diphtheriae.
  • Consists of two fragments (Bipartite), A and B, with a molecular weight of approximately 62,000 daltons.

Role of Lysogenic β-phage
  • The tox gene is carried by a lysogenic β-phage.
  • Only phage-infected strains produce toxin; nontoxigenic strains can become toxigenic if infected.
  • Corynebacterium diphtheriae remains localized at the infection site, with only the toxin entering circulation, causing toxaemia but not bacteremia.

Mechanism of Action
  • Fragment B binds host cell receptors, facilitating fragment A entry into the cytoplasm.
  • Fragment A catalyses ADP-ribosylation of EF-2, halting protein synthesis.

Systemic Effects
  • DT spreads via blood, causing myocarditis and neuritis.
  • Myocarditis is potentially fatal.

Factors Affecting Production
  • Influenced by environmental factors: alkaline pH (7.8-8.0), oxygen, and iron concentration in the growth medium.
  • High production with low iron availability; iron addition inhibits production.

Toxoid Formation
  • Treatment with formalin (0.2-0.4%), and incubation at 37°C for 4-6 weeks converts DT to toxoid.
  • Toxoid lacks toxicity but induces an immune response; used in vaccines.

Immunity
  • Immunity is primarily mediated by antitoxin antibodies neutralizing DT.

 

Clostridium toxin (Option B): Clostridium species produce neurotoxins that act by blocking neurotransmitter release, not EF-2 inhibition.

Bacillus toxin (Option C): Bacillus anthracis produces anthrax toxin (PA, EF, LF), which disrupts cell signaling via adenylate cyclase, not EF-2 inhibition.

Vibrio toxin (Option D): Vibrio cholerae produces cholera toxin, which increases cAMP via ADP-ribosylation of Gs protein, causing watery diarrhea but does not affect EF-2.

questions.text: Which of the following extracellular adhesions is disrupted by Vibrio cholerae?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Occludens

Explanation:

  • V. cholerae produces Zonula Occludens Toxin (Zot), which opens tight junctions in the small intestine, increasing permeability and fluid loss, contributing to profuse watery diarrhea.
  • Encoded by the zot gene within the CTXф phage genome, alongside cholera toxin (CT) and Ace enterotoxin genes.
  • Zot is anchored to the outer membrane of V. cholerae and E. coli when expressed in both.
  • Functions of Zot Domains:
    • N-terminal: Involved in CTXф phage morphogenesis, similar to gene I products of filamentous phages.
    • C-terminal: Responsible for enterotoxic effects.

 

Integrin (Option A): Integrins are transmembrane receptors involved in cell-extracellular matrix adhesion. Vibrio cholerae does not directly target integrins as part of its pathogenic mechanism.

Cadherin (Option B): Cadherins are calcium-dependent cell adhesion molecules primarily involved in adherens junctions. Vibrio cholerae does not disrupt cadherin-mediated adhesion.

questions.text: A sewage worker presented with abdominal pain, jaundice, conjunctival injection, and hematuria for the past 5 days. Which of the following is the investigation of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Microscopic Agglutination Test (MAT)

Explanation:

  • Microscopic agglutination test (MAT) is the gold standard test for diagnosing Leptospirosis. It detects Leptospira-specific antibodies by agglutination of live leptospiral antigens. It is highly sensitive and specific for confirming leptospiral infection.

Leptospirosis

Agent
  • Leptospira interrogans (zoonotic bacteria)

Reservoir
  • Rodents (Ratus norvegicus, Mus musculus) and domestic animals

Source
  • Direct contact or contamination with excreta, urine of infected animals.

At risk individuals
  • Males 20-45 years (most common)
  • Urine-contaminated mud(Soil) or water
    • Sports: Rafting, fishing and swimming
    • Rice field workers, sewer workers, animal handlers

Mode of transmission
  • Direct contact: Urine through skin abrasion
  • Indirect contact: Contact of broken skin with soil, water, vegetation
  • Droplet infection: Inhalation while milking cows.

Incubation
  • 4-20 days

Diagnosis
  • Clinical features
  • Dark Field examination: Thin and motile spirochete.
  • IgM ELISA: High sensitivity
  • Labs: Elevated liver enzymes, increased bilirubin, thrombocytopenia

Incorrect Options:

Widal test (Option A): The Widal test is used for typhoid fever (Salmonella typhi) and is not useful for diagnosing Leptospirosis.

Weil-Felix reaction (Option C): Weil-Felix is a serological test for Rickettsial infections and is not specific for Leptospirosis.

Paul-Bunnell test (Option D): The Paul-Bunnell test is used to detect heterophile antibodies in infectious mononucleosis (caused by Epstein-Barr virus) and has no role in diagnosing Leptospirosis.

questions.text: A child was brought with complaints of high fever, multiple seizures, headache, and neck rigidity. CSF analysis revealed low glucose, high protein, and many polymorphs. The CSF culture showed pleomorphic gram-negative bacilli. What is true about the causative organism?

choices.text: Produces non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar
Exhibits satellitism around Staphylococcus aureus colonies
It exhibits alpha hemolysis on sheep blood agar

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Exhibits satellitism around Staphylococcus aureus colonies

Explanation:

  • The pleomorphic gram-negative bacilli in CSF culture suggest Haemophilus influenzae, a major cause of bacterial meningitis in children.
  • H. influenzae requires Factor X (hemin) and Factor V (NAD) for growth. Staphylococcus aureus releases NAD, promoting the growth of H. influenzae around its colonies, a phenomenon known as satellitism.
  • The type b capsular polysaccharide (polyribosylribitol phosphate or PRP) is the most virulent serotype, particularly in unvaccinated children under 5 years old, often causing invasive diseases like meningitis.

Clinical features:

  • Meningitis: Fever, irritability, neck stiffness
  • Other invasive diseases: Epiglottitis, pneumonia, septic arthritis
  • Nontypeable strains often cause mucosal infections like otitis media, sinusitis

Diagnosis:

  • CSF analysis in meningitis: elevated protein, low glucose, pleocytosis
  • Gram stain: small gram-negative coccobacilli
  • Culture on chocolate agar
  • Antigen detection tests (latex agglutination) for rapid diagnosis
  • PCR for definitive identification and serotyping

Treatment:

  • Empiric therapy: Third-generation cephalosporins (ceftriaxone or cefotaxime)
  • Alternative: Chloramphenicol (if cephalosporin allergy)
  • Duration: Usually 10 days for meningitis

Incorrect Options:

It is bacitracin sensitive (Option A): Bacitracin sensitivity is a characteristic of Haemophilus ducreyi, not Haemophilus influenzae.

Produces non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar (Option B): H. influenzae does not grow on MacConkey agar, as it requires Factor X (hemin) and Factor V (NAD), which are absent in this medium.

It exhibits alpha hemolysis on sheep blood agar (Option D): H. influenzae does not hemolyze red blood cells, whereas Streptococcus pneumoniae (another common cause of meningitis) exhibits alpha hemolysis on sheep blood agar.

questions.text: A man presents with dysuria and urethral discharge after having unprotected sexual intercourse. Gram staining of the purulent discharge is shown in the image. What is the treatment of choice for this infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ceftriaxone + Azithromycin

Explanation:

  • The presence of Gram-negative diplococci in purulent urethral discharge suggests Neisseria gonorrhoeae, a common cause of gonococcal urethritis.
  • First-line treatment recommended by WHO is a single dose of intramuscular Ceftriaxone (500 mg) + oral Azithromycin (1 g) to cover both gonorrhea and possible Chlamydia trachomatis co-infection.

Urethritis

Etiology

Infectious Causes:

  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae (gonococcal)
  • Chlamydia trachomatis (nongonococcal)
  • Mycoplasma genitalium (recurrent urethritis)
  • Trichomonas vaginalis (protozoal)
  • Other: HSV, Treponema pallidum, Candida, Corynebacterium, Haemophilus influenzae

Non-Infectious Causes:

  • Irritants (soaps, spermicides, tight clothing)
  • Trauma (catheterization, instrumentation)
  • Menopause (low estrogen, atrophic vaginitis)

Clinical Presentation
  • Symptoms:
    • Dysuria (worse in morning, alcohol-exacerbated)
    • Urethral discharge (varies by pathogen)
    • Urethral pruritus, orchalgia (testicular pain in men)
    • Systemic symptoms rare (except viral causes)
  • Discharge Characteristics:
    • Thick, yellow-green → N. gonorrhoeae
    • Clear, white → C. trachomatis
    • Purulent/mucopurulent → M. genitalium

Diagnosis

Clinical suspicion in sexually active individuals with urethral symptoms.

Laboratory Tests:

  • Gram stain: Gram-negative intracellular diplococci (gonococcal)
  • NAAT (preferred): Detects C. trachomatis, N. gonorrhoeae, T. vaginalis, M. genitalium
  • Additional: Cultures, fungal KOH prep, NAAT for syphilis/HIV, pregnancy testing, wet mount for T. vaginalis (low sensitivity).

Alternative Methods:

  • MB/GV smear (similar to gram stain, sensitivity 97.3%)
  • Urethral culture (for N. gonorrhoeae resistance testing)
  • C. trachomatis suspected if pyuria present but no bacteria on stain/culture
  • M. genitalium confirmed only via NAAT (limited availability)

Emerging Pathogens

Haemophilus spp. increasingly linked to nongonococcal urethritis, especially with oral exposure.

Treatment

Indications for Antibiotics:

  • Positive gram stain/culture
  • Contact with an infected partner
  • Clinical urethritis without confirmed etiology if follow-up is uncertain.

Gonococcal Urethritis:

  • Ceftriaxone 500 mg IM (if <150 kg) or 1 g IM (if ≥150 kg)
  • If C. Trachomatis not ruled out: Add Doxycycline 100 mg PO BID x 7 days
  • Alternatives: Gentamicin + Azithromycin or Cefixime

Nongonococcal Urethritis:

  • Doxycycline 100 mg PO BID x 7 days (preferred)
  • Alternative: Azithromycin (multi-day better than single dose)

Persistent/Recurrent Urethritis:

  • M. genitalium suspected: Doxycycline 7 days → Moxifloxacin 400 mg PO daily x 7 days
  • If T. vaginalis suspected: NAAT confirmation or empiric Metronidazole 2 g PO

Special Cases

Pregnancy:

  • Azithromycin 1 g PO (preferred)
  • Alternatives: Amoxicillin, Erythromycin (varied dosing)
  • Avoid: Doxycycline, Quinolones

Resistant M. Genitalium: Moxifloxacin or Pristinamycin

T. vaginalis Treatment:

  • Women: Metronidazole 500 mg PO BID x 7 days
  • Men: Metronidazole 2 g PO single dose
  • Sexual partners must be treated to prevent reinfection.

Incorrect Options:

Erythromycin (Option A): Erythromycin is not effective against gonorrhea and is primarily used for Chlamydia infections in neonates (ophthalmia neonatorum prophylaxis).

Ciprofloxacin + Azithromycin (Option B): Fluoroquinolone resistance is widespread in N. gonorrhoeae, making ciprofloxacin no longer recommended for treatment.

Penicillin G (Option D): Penicillin-resistant N. gonorrhoeae strains are common, leading to the discontinuation of penicillin-based therapy.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents with fever, abdominal pain, and diarrhea for 3 days. He reports consuming raw fish prior to symptom onset. He is hemodynamically stable, and stool examination reveals no pus cells. Culture grows on Wagatsuma agar. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Vibrio parahaemolyticus

Explanation:

  • Vibrio parahaemolyticus is a halophilic Gram-negative bacterium associated with seafood consumption, particularly raw fish or shellfish.
  • It causes self-limited gastroenteritis with watery diarrhea, fever, and abdominal pain.
  • It grows on Wagatsuma agar, a selective medium used to detect Kanagawa-positive strains producing hemolysin.

 

Vibrio parahaemolyticus Infection

Pathophysiology

  • Infection Routes:
    • Ingestion → Gastroenteritis.
    • Wound exposure → Localized infection.
    • Severe cases → Spreads to blood (esp. in immunocompromised).
  • Virulence Factors:
    • Thermostable Direct Hemolysin (TDH) – Pore-forming toxin, unclear mechanism.
    • Type 3 secretion system – Similar to other Gram-negative bacteria.
  • Most cases are self-limiting enteritis.

 

Evaluation

  • Gold standard: Stool culture on TCBS agar.
  • Additional tests: Blood/wound cultures if sepsis/wound infection suspected.

 

Treatment & Management

  • Supportive care: IV fluids, electrolyte correction.
  • Antibiotics (for severe cases):
    • Gastroenteritis: Doxycycline.
    • Wound infections: Doxycycline or minocycline.
    • Severe infections/sepsis: Add 3rd-gen cephalosporin.

 

Vibrio cholerae (Option A): Vibrio cholerae causes profuse watery diarrhea ("rice-water stools") due to cholera toxin-mediated chloride secretion. It does not typically cause fever or abdominal pain and does not grow on Wagatsuma agar.

  • Thiosulfate-Citrate-Bile Salts-Sucrose (TCBS) Agar:
    • Differentiates between sucrose fermenters (like Vibrio cholerae) and non-sucrose fermenters (such as Vibrio parahaemolyticus).
    • Vibrio cholerae produces yellow colonies due to sucrose fermentation.

 

Salmonella typhi (Option B): Salmonella typhi causes typhoid fever, characterized by stepwise fever, constipation or "pea-soup" diarrhea, and hepatosplenomegaly. It does not grow on Wagatsuma agar.

Shigella sonnei (Option C): Shigella sonnei causes bacillary dysentery, characterized by fever, abdominal cramps, and bloody/mucoid diarrhea with pus cells. The stool in this case lacks pus cells, ruling out Shigella.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with multiple sexual partners presents with a palmoplantar rash. On examination, he has mucocutaneous papules on the scrotum and lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Secondary syphilis

Explanation:

  • Secondary syphilis is the second stage of syphilis, which occurs if primary syphilis is left untreated. It typically presents a few weeks to several months after the initial chancre has healed. This stage is marked by systemic manifestations and can affect multiple organ systems.

Clinical Features:

1. Rash: The most characteristic feature is a diffuse, non-pruritic rash that can appear anywhere on the body. It often presents as reddish-brown spots (macules) and may also include raised lesions (papules). The rash is polymorphous, non-infectious, and never vesicular

2. Mucous Membrane Lesion- Condylomata Lata: These are broad, wart-like lesions that can appear in moist areas, such as the oral cavity, genital region, and perineum. They are highly infectious.The oral features of secondary syphilis can be painless or painful erythematous lesions, grayish-white mucous patches, or irregular linear erosions termed snail track ulcers

3. Moth eaten alopecia-nonscarring, patchy hair loss with a "moth-eaten" appearance, most commonly affecting the scalp. It is considered a pathognomonic sign of the disease but can also affect other hair-bearing areas.

4. Blushke olendroff sign-The Buschke-Ollendorff sign in secondary syphilis and cutaneous vasculitis involves deep dermal tenderness when pressing on lesions, such as syphilitic papules, with a pinhead.

5. Lymphadenopathy: Generalized painless lymphadenopathy,characteristic epitrochlear node involvement

6. Systemic Symptoms: Patients may experience flu-like symptoms, including mild fever, malaise, and fatigue.

7. Rarely, secondary syphilis can lead to neurological symptoms or ocular involvement, though this is more common in tertiary syphilis.

Diagnosis: Serological Testing:

  1. Non-Treponemal Tests: RPR (Rapid Plasma Reagin) and VDRL (Venereal Disease Research Laboratory) are used for screening. These tests detect nonspecific antibodies and can be positive in other conditions.
  2. Treponemal Tests: FTA-ABS (Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption) confirms the diagnosis by detecting antibodies specific to Treponema pallidum.

Treatment:

  • The standard treatment for secondary syphilis is Benzathine penicillin G. Dosage: 2.4 million units intramuscularly in a single dose.
  • For those allergic to penicillin, alternatives such as doxycycline or tetracycline can be used.

Complications: If left untreated, secondary syphilis can progress to the latent stage and eventually tertiary syphilis, which can lead to serious complications, including cardiovascular, neurological, and systemic damage.

 

Psoriasis (Option A): Psoriasis presents with well-demarcated, erythematous plaques covered with silvery scales, commonly on the extensor surfaces (elbows, knees). It is not associated with mucocutaneous lesions or lymphadenopathy.

Primary syphilis (Option C): Primary syphilis presents as a painless genital chancre without systemic symptoms. The rash and mucosal lesions seen in this case are characteristic of secondary syphilis, not primary.

Tertiary syphilis (Option D): Tertiary syphilis occurs years after untreated infection and presents with gummas (granulomatous lesions), neurosyphilis, or cardiovascular complications. The rash and lymphadenopathy seen here are more indicative of secondary syphilis.

questions.text: Mode of transmission of abdominal TB includes all except

choices.text: Direct spread from mesenteric lymph nodes

questions.solution:
Feco-oral route is not a mode of transmission of abdominal TB.

  • Tuberculosis bacteria reach the GIT via haematogenous spread, ingestion of infected sputum, direct spread from infected contiguous lymph nodes and fallopian tubes but not through feco-oral route.

 

Gastrointestinal Tuberculosis

Mechanisms of Infection
  • Swallowing of sputum with direct seeding.
  • Hematogenous spread.
  • Ingestion of contaminated bovine milk (common in developing areas).

Common sites of infection
  • Terminal ileum and cecum.

Symptoms
  • Abdominal: Pain (similar to appendicitis), swelling, obstruction, hematochezia, palpable abdominal mass.
  • Systemic: Fever, weight loss, anorexia, night sweats.
  • Complications: Ulcerations and fistulae (mimicking Crohn’s disease); anal fistula suggests rectal TB.

Diagnosis

  • Surgery is required to obtain histologic and culture specimens intraoperatively.
  • Differential Diagnosis: Difficult to distinguish from Crohn’s disease.

 

Tuberculous Peritonitis

Pathophysiology
  • Results from the direct spread of tubercle bacilli from ruptured lymph nodes or intra-abdominal organs (e.g., genital TB in women), or hematogenous spread.

Symptoms
  • Abdominal: Nonspecific abdominal pain, ascites.
  • Systemic: Fever.
  • Complication: Coexistence with cirrhosis complicates diagnosis.

Diagnosis
  • Paracentesis: Reveals exudative fluid with high protein content and lymphocytic leukocytosis (neutrophils may predominate at times).
  • Direct Smear/Culture: Low yield; culturing large volumes of ascitic fluid may improve results.
  • Peritoneal Biopsy: Typically needed for diagnosis, best obtained via laparoscopy.

Treatment
  • Surgical intervention may be required for diagnosis and management in many cases.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with fever, headache, photophobia, and neck rigidity for the last 2 days. He had undergone a heart transplant one year back and is on immunomodulatory drugs. On microscopy, differential motility was seen, non-motile at 37°C, and motile at 25°C. What is the most likely organism causing this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Listeria

Explanation:

Listeria monocytogenes infection in adults can lead to meningitis, particularly in elderly individuals or those who are immunocompromised.

 

Listeria monocytogenes

Mode of Transmission
  • Contaminated food
  • Vertical transmission (mother to fetus, during birth)

Common Food Sources
  • Contaminated coleslaw
  • Milk, Soft cheeses
  • "Ready-to-eat" foods (delicatessen meat, uncooked hotdogs)

Age Groups at Risk
  • Neonates
  • Elderly individuals

Increased Risk Factors
  • Use of proton pump inhibitors
  • Pregnant women
  • Immunocompromised individuals

Survival in Food
  • Survives refrigeration (4°C)
  • Found in stored foods (aged soft cheeses, packaged meats, milk, cold salads)

Infection Type
  • Sporadic
  • Outbreaks can occur

Psychrotrophic
  • L. monocytogenes is a psychrotrophic organism with an optimum growth temperature of 30ºC to 37ºC but has the ability to grow at a wide range of temperatures from 1ºC to 45ºC.

Motility
  • Shows Tumbling and Differential motility(motile at 25.C by forming actin rockets, non motile at 37.C)

Pathogenesis
  • Intracellular survival: lysis of phagosome (listeriolysin O)
  • Host cell actin polymerization (cell membrane approach)
  • Direct cell-to-cell spread (listeriopods)

Clinical Manifestations
  • Neonatal listeriosis: Early-onset and late-onset disease
  • Pregnant women:
    • Granulomatosis infantiseptica in baby in 3rd trimester
    • Fetal complications (abortion, preterm delivery)
    • Maternal complications (flu-like symptoms, bacteremia, rarely meningitis)
  • Adults:
    • Bacteremia and meningitis (elderly, >60 years)
    • Immunosuppression- higher risk (steroid therapy, HIV, diabetes, malignancy)
    • Post-kidney transplant meningitis (1-month post-transplant)
    • Gastroenteritis (consumption of contaminated milk, meat, salads)

Streptococcus (Option B) Streptococcus pneumoniae is a leading cause of bacterial meningitis but is not motile at any temperature.

Staphylococcus (Option C) Staphylococcus aureus and Staphylococcus epidermidis can cause meningitis, but they are non-motile and does not exhibit temperature-dependent motility.

Giardia lamblia (Option D) a protozoan parasite that causes giardiasis (diarrheal disease), not meningitis..

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of fever for 3 days and general fatigue. Echocardiography revealed vegetations on the valves, and a blood culture was performed. The organism in the culture showed alpha hemolysis on blood agar and was resistant to optochin and bile. Which of the following bacteria is most commonly implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Streptococcus sanguis

Explanation:

The patients presentation is suggestive of infective endocarditis

Alpha Hemolytic Streptococcus:

  • Part of the normal flora of the human mouth, throat, and gastrointestinal tract.
  • Exhibits alpha-hemolysis on blood agar, leading to a partial or greenish discoloration around colonies.
  • Includes multiple species such as S. mitis, S. mutans, S. sanguinis (leads to SABE), and S. salivarius.

Epidemiology:
  • Dental procedures can introduce Streptococcus viridans into the bloodstream, potentially leading to infective endocarditis.
  • Patients with pre-existing heart conditions, such as valvular heart disease or prosthetic valves, are at higher risk.

Infection Mechanism:
  • Capable of producing biofilms, aiding in adherence to heart valves, and resistance to phagocytosis and antibiotics.
  • Production of extracellular polysaccharides enhances its ability to colonize and persist in host tissues.

Clinical Presentation:
  • Symptoms can include fever, chills, heart murmur, fatigue, and signs of embolic events such as petechiae or splinter hemorrhages.
  • Complications may involve heart failure, systemic embolization, and severe valve dysfunction.

Diagnosis:
  • Blood cultures are essential for identifying the causative organism.
  • Echocardiography (especially transesophageal echocardiography) is used to visualize vegetations on the heart valves

Treatment:
  • Prolonged antibiotic therapy, often involves penicillin or ceftriaxone combined with an aminoglycoside.
  • In some cases, surgical intervention may be necessary to repair or replace damaged valves.

Escherichia coli (Option B) (abbreviated as E. coli) are bacteria found in the environment, foods, and intestines of people and animals. Some kinds of E. coli can cause diarrhea, while others cause urinary tract infections, respiratory illness and pneumonia, and other illnesses. questions.text: In a resource-limited setting, what diagnostic method can be utilized to identify the condition when there is a visible painless hardened genital ulcer following unprotected sexual activity, as reported by a truck driver?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Dark field microscopy

Explanation:

The patient's presentation of a painless, indurated genital ulcer with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse is suggestive of syphilis caused by Treponema pallidum

  • It can be seen in a low-resource setting by examining clinical specimens from the ulcer under dark field microscopy. It enables the direct viewing of the spirochetes in the samples, which is especially helpful when an active ulcer is present.
  • Using a dark field microscope, which illuminates the material with tangential or oblique light, the motile spirochetes can be observed as dazzling, silver-white, or golden-yellow corkscrew-like structures on a dark backdrop.

 

Leptospira Culture media and Serological test:

Culture Media:

  • Ellinghausen-McCullough-Johnson-Harris (EMJH) medium is commonly used for culturing Leptospira species showing Dinger’s ring.

 

  • It is a semi-solid or liquid medium that supports the slow-growing leptospires, often requiring incubation for weeks.
  • Specimen Sources: Blood, urine, or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) samples are often used, depending on the stage of infection.
  • Other culture media are Korthoff and Fletcher.

Serological tests:

  • Non-Treponemal Tests:
    • VDRL (Venereal Disease Research Laboratory) and RPR (Rapid Plasma Reagin): These tests are used for screening. They measure nonspecific antibodies that may indicate syphilis but can also be positive in other conditions (like pregnancy, lupus, or infections).
  • Treponemal Tests:
    • TP-PA (Treponema pallidum particle agglutination), EIA (Enzyme Immunoassays), and FTA-ABS (Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption): These tests are more specific to syphilis and confirm the diagnosis. They detect antibodies specific to the syphilis bacterium.

Other Investigations:

  • CSF Analysis
  • Darkfield Microscopy: In the presence of a chancre or other lesions, a sample may be taken to observe the organism directly under a microscope, which can confirm syphilis.

Treatment:

  • Treatment in this stage typically involves a course of antibiotics, most commonly penicillin. Benzathine penicillin G is the recommended treatment. A single intramuscular injection (2.4 million units) is typically sufficient.
  • Alternative for Penicillin Allergies: Doxycycline (100 mg orally twice daily for 14 days) or tetracycline can be used for those allergic to penicillin, but penicillin is preferred.
  • For pregnant patients allergic to penicillin, desensitization may be considered as it is the only effective proven treatment effective for preventing transmission to the fetus.
  • Early diagnosis and treatment of primary syphilis are vital. If left untreated, the infection can progress to secondary, latent, and tertiary stages.

 

Fluorescent treponema antibody absorption (FTA-ABS) (Option B) is a serological test used to detect antibodies against Treponema pallidum. It is not used for direct visualization of the organism and requires a laboratory setup for testing.

Venereal disease research laboratory (VDRL) test (Option C) The VDRL test is also used to detect syphilis. It works by detecting antibodies that the body makes in case of Treponema pallidum infection and requires a laboratory setup for the test.

Treponema pallidum immobilization (TPI) test (Option D) A specialized serological test called the TPI test is performed to validate the presence of Treponema pallidum antibodies in the blood and requires a laboratory setup for the test.

questions.text: A patient presented with severe watery diarrhea resembling rice water stools. Damage to which structure is most likely responsible for this diarrhea?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Zona Occludens

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario of severe rice watery diarrhea is indicative of Cholera.

Junctions and their function:

In epithelial cells, junctions are organized in a specific pattern from the apical to the basal surface.

  • At the apical region, the cell membranes fuse to form a tight junction (zonula occludens), which encircles the cells.
  • Below this is the zonula adherens, where proteins link to the cytoskeleton of both cells, separated by a small intercellular space with adhesion proteins.
  • Further down is a desmosome, a spotlike structure with attachment proteins connecting the cells.

The sequence of junctions from apical to basal is:

  1. Tight junctions (Zonula occludens)
  2. Adherens junctions (Zonula adherens)
  3. Desmosomes (Macula adherens)
  4. Gap junctions
  5. Hemidesmosomes

 

  

 

 

Functions:

  • Tight junctions (Zonula occludens) (Option A): Found in epithelia of the stomach, intestines, and bladder, these prevent the passage of substances between cells by fusing membranes with claudin proteins.
  • Zonula adherens (Option C ruled out): Links adjacent cells through cytoskeleton attachments, reinforced by actin filaments.
  • Desmosomes: Seen in skin and cardiac muscle, they prevent cell separation under mechanical stress by anchoring to intermediate filaments.
  • Hemidesmosomes (Option D ruled out): at the base of epithelial cells, anchoring them to the basement membrane and connective tissue.
  • Gap junctions (Option B ruled out): Channels (connexons) between cells allowing molecular and electrical communication, crucial for cardiac muscle and nerve function.

Cholera MOA:

Mechanism of Action

  • Mucus Crossing: Hemagglutinin-protease cleaves mucus and fibronectin.
  • Epithelial Adhesion: Toxin coregulated pilus (TCP) helps the bacteria adhere to the epithelial surface without invading or damaging cells, remaining attached throughout the infection.

Enterotoxin

  • Structure: Consists of one A (active) subunit and five B (binding) subunits.
  • Dissociation in Enterocytes:
    • A subunit splits into A1 and A2 fragments.
    • A1 Fragment Action: Activates cellular adenylate cyclase, leading to increased cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels. This results in an outflow of large quantities of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen, causing watery diarrhea.
  • Receptor Binding: B subunits attach to GM1 ganglioside receptors on the surface of jejunal epithelial cells.

Clinical Features

  • Stool Characteristics: "Rice water" stools with a mild sweet odor.
  • Diarrhea Progression: Initially mild diarrhea and vomiting, rapidly progressing to sudden massive diarrhea.
  • Electrolyte Imbalance: Hypokalemia, base-deficit acidosis.
  • Shock: Due to fluid loss and electrolyte imbalance.

questions.text: A patient was suspected of having acute brucellosis. A serum sample was sent for a standard agglutination test. It came out to be negative initially, but after serial dilutions of the serum sample, the test turned out to be positive. Which of the following is responsible for the initial negative test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Prozone phenomenon

Explanation:

  • The prozone phenomenon occurs when there is an excess of antibodies in the serum sample relative to the antigen during an agglutination test. This excess of antibodies can prevent the formation of an optimal antigen-antibody complex, which is necessary for visible agglutination. As a result, the test appears negative initially, but after performing serial dilutions of the serum (reducing the concentration of antibodies), the agglutination becomes visible and the test turns positive.

Brucella features:

  • Brucella melitensis is the most pathogenic species for humans.

Characteristics of Brucella:

Biochemical Properties

Often exhibit a bipolar staining appearance

Utilize oxygen but do not typically ferment carbohydrates

Killed by pasteurization

Zoonotic Nature: Primarily affects goats, sheep, cattle, buffaloes, and pigs. Humans can become infected through contact with infected animals or consumption of contaminated animal products

Clinical Presentation in Humans:

  • Symptoms: Intermittent fever, loss of appetite, nausea, muscular and articular pains, fatigue, sweating, and joint pain
  • Also known as Undulant fever, Mediterranean fever, Maltese fever
  • Diagnosis is challenging due to nonspecific symptoms and relies on high clinical suspicion

Diagnosis of Brucellosis:

Laboratory Testing Methods:

  • Blood Culture:
    • Most definitive diagnostic method
    • Requires trypticase soy broth or brucella broth in biphasic blood culture bottles (e.g., Castaneda method)
    • Large blood volume (5 ml) recommended due to low bacterial load
    • Incubation at 37°C under 5-10% CO2 for at least 6-8 weeks
    • Positive in approximately 30-50% of cases
    • Bone marrow cultures may have a higher yield
  • Serological Tests:
    • Used when culture methods are unsuccessful

Serological Test Types:

Test

Description

Key Points

Standard Agglutination Test (SAT)

Tube agglutination test using serial dilutions of patient's serum and killed B. abortus antigen
  • Significant titer: 160 or more.
  • Acute brucellosis titer: 640 or more within 3-4 weeks.
  • Prozone phenomenon common.
  • False positives with cholera, tularemia, yersinia infection, or immunization

Complement Fixation Test

Detects IgG antibodies
  • Valuable in chronic cases

ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay)

Distinguishes between IgM and IgG antibodies
  • Useful for differentiating acute from chronic infections

Rapid Tests

Includes rapid dipstick tests and Rose Bengal card test
  • Quick results.
  • Can be used for initial screening

Incomplete antibodies (Option A): Incomplete antibodies are those that cannot cause agglutination on their own because they are not capable of forming a stable cross-link between the antigen and the antibody. However, they are not typically the cause of a negative test that turns positive after dilution. Incomplete antibodies may still contribute to a weaker or partial reaction but do not explain the phenomenon of dilution-dependent agglutination.

Complement inactivation (Option B): Complement inactivation refers to the loss of complement activity in a serum sample, which can affect some tests that depend on the complement system for full reaction (e.g., some hemolysis or lysis tests). This does not explain the initial negative and later positive agglutination result seen in the prozone phenomenon.

Post zone phenomenon (Option D): The postzone phenomenon occurs when there is an excess of antigen relative to the antibody, leading to a lack of agglutination because the antigen is in excess and does not form sufficient complexes with the antibodies. This does not apply to the situation described, where the serum antibody concentration was initially too high, not the antigen concentration.

questions.text: One week after having unprotected sexual intercourse, a 25-year-old male develops urethral discharge as shown in the image below. What is the most likely causative organism for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Neisseria gonorrheae

Explanation:

  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae is the bacterium responsible for gonorrhea, a sexually transmitted infection (STI). One of the classic symptoms of gonorrhea in men is urethral discharge, which is typically yellow or purulent in appearance, matching the presentation in the image described.
  • Gonorrhea typically presents 1 to 7 days after exposure, making it a plausible cause for the symptoms seen in this 25-year-old male who developed symptoms one week after unprotected sexual intercourse.
  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae is commonly transmitted through unprotected sexual contact, affecting the urethra, rectum, and throat, and can lead to symptoms like painful urination and purulent discharge.

Neisseria Gonorrhoeae

Clinical Features

Men

Urethritis, purulent urethral discharge, dysuria, epididymitis, prostatitis.

Women

Cervicitis, vaginal discharge, pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), dysuria, and intermenstrual bleeding.

Rarely can cause Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome.

Pharyngeal Infection

Often asymptomatic, sore throat, pharyngitis.

Rectal Infection

Proctitis, rectal discharge, pain, and tenesmus, may be asymptomatic.

Disseminated Gonococcal Infection (DGI)

Fever, dermatitis, polyarthralgia, septic arthritis.

Neonates

Ophthalmia neonatorum, conjunctivitis, potential for blindness if untreated.

Diagnosis

Gram Stain

Gram-negative diplococci within polymorphonuclear leukocytes (particularly useful in men).

Culture

Thayer-Martin or other selective media, oxidase-positive, and carbohydrate utilization tests.

NAAT (Nucleic Acid Amplification Test)

Highly sensitive and specific, recommended for urogenital, pharyngeal, and rectal specimens.

Serological Tests

Not commonly used due to lower sensitivity and specificity compared to NAAT and culture.

Treatment- Green STD kit

First-Line Therapy

Ceftriaxone 500 mg IM as a single dose PLUS doxycycline 100 mg orally twice daily for 7 days (if chlamydial co-infection is not excluded).

Alternative Therapy

Gentamicin 240 mg IM as a single dose PLUS azithromycin 2 g orally as a single dose (if ceftriaxone is not available).

Incorrect Options:

Ureaplasma urealyticum (Option B): This bacterium can also cause urethritis and other genitourinary tract infections, but it typically results in a non-purulent discharge, which is less likely to be as yellow and purulent as seen in gonorrhea. Ureaplasma infections can be more asymptomatic and are often detected in the context of chronic symptoms or infertility.

Herpes simplex virus (Option C) (HSV): HSV typically presents with painful vesicles or ulcers on the genitalia, not a purulent urethral discharge. HSV can cause urethritis, but the classic presentation would include painful sores or blisters, which would likely be present in the image if HSV were the cause.

Trichomonas vaginalis (Option D): Trichomoniasis is caused by a protozoan parasite and can cause urethritis and discharge. However, the discharge is typically frothy, yellow-green, and has a foul odor, which is different from the purulent discharge seen with gonorrhea. Additionally, trichomoniasis usually presents with vaginal symptoms in women, though it can affect men as well.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms belongs to the given life cycle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Leptospira

Explanation:

  • Leptospira species are spirochetes responsible for leptospirosis. Their life cycle involves animal reservoirs, particularly rodents, which excrete the bacteria in urine. Humans acquire infection through exposure to contaminated water or soil, making this the correct answer.

 

Leptospirosis

Agent
  • Leptospira interrogans (zoonotic bacteria)

Reservoir
  • Rodents (Ratus norvegicus, Mus musculus) and domestic animals

Source
  • Direct contact or contamination with excreta, urine of infected animals.

At risk individuals
  • Males 20-45 years (most common)
  • Urine-contaminated mud(Soil) or water
    • Sports: rafting, fishing and swimming
    • Rice field workers, sewer workers, animal handlers

Mode of transmission
  • Direct contact: Urine through skin abrasion
  • Indirect contact: Contact of broken skin with soil, water, vegetation
  • Droplet infection: Inhalation while milking cows.

Incubation
  • 4-20 days

Diagnosis
  • Clinical features
  • Dark Field examination: Thin and motile spirochete.
  • IgM ELISA: High sensitivity
  • Labs: Elevated liver enzymes, increased bilirubin, thrombocytopenia

Incorrect Options:

Hantavirus (Option B): Hantavirus is transmitted via aerosolized rodent excreta, particularly urine and feces, but it does not have a distinct life cycle involving waterborne transmission like Leptospira. Instead, it primarily causes hantavirus pulmonary syndrome or hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome.

Yersinia pestis (Option C): Yersinia pestis, the causative agent of plague, is transmitted through flea bites and direct contact with infected animals. It does not involve a waterborne life cycle linked to urine contamination.

Salmonella typhi (Option D): Salmonella typhi causes typhoid fever and is transmitted via the fecal-oral route through contaminated food and water, not through urine-contaminated environments like Leptospira.

questions.text: The disruption of which of the following structures is responsible for the watery diarrhea seen in cholera caused by Vibrio cholerae?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Zonula occludens

Explanation:

  • Zonula occludens, also known as tight junctions, maintain the selective permeability of the intestinal epithelium.
  • Cholera toxin binds to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on intestinal epithelial cells. Once internalized, the A subunit of the toxin activates adenylate cyclase, leading to an increase in cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels. Elevated cAMP disrupts ion transport, causing a significant efflux of chloride ions and water into the intestinal lumen, resulting in profuse watery diarrhea.

Pathogenesis

  • Natural Host: Only humans.
  • Transmission: Orally through contaminated water or food.
  • Incubation Period: 1-5 days.

Mechanism of Action

  • Mucus Crossing: Hemagglutinin-protease cleaves mucus and fibronectin.
  • Epithelial Adhesion: Toxin coregulated pilus (TCP) helps the bacteria adhere to the epithelial surface without invading or damaging cells, remaining attached throughout the infection.

Enterotoxin

  • Structure: Consists of one A (active) subunit and five B (binding) subunits.
  • Dissociation in Enterocytes:
    • A subunit splits into A1 and A2 fragments.
    • A1 Fragment Action: Activates cellular adenylate cyclase, leading to increased cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels. This results in an outflow of large quantities of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen, causing watery diarrhea.
  • Receptor Binding: B subunits attach to GM1 ganglioside receptors on the surface of jejunal epithelial cells.

Clinical Features

  • Stool Characteristics: "Rice water" stools with a mild sweet odor.
  • Diarrhea Progression: Initially mild diarrhea and vomiting, rapidly progressing to sudden massive diarrhea.
  • Electrolyte Imbalance: Hypokalemia, base-deficit acidosis.
  • Shock: Due to fluid loss and electrolyte imbalance.

Complications

  • Muscular Cramps
  • Renal Failure
  • Pulmonary Edema
  • Cardiac Arrhythmias
  • Paralytic Ileus

Incorrect Options:

Intercalated discs (Option A): Intercalated discs are specialized junctions in cardiac muscle that facilitate electrical and mechanical coupling between cardiomyocytes. They are not involved in intestinal permeability or cholera-induced diarrhea.

Macula densa (Option B): The macula densa is a group of specialized epithelial cells in the distal convoluted tubule of the kidney involved in regulating blood pressure and sodium balance. It does not play a role in cholera pathophysiology.

Hemidesmosomes (Option D): Hemidesmosomes anchor epithelial cells to the basement membrane and are involved in structural integrity rather than regulating paracellular transport or fluid secretion.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever and chills. Throat examination reveals swollen glands and a thick, whitish membrane over the tonsils. Albert staining is ordered. What are the constituents of Albert’s stain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Toluidine blue and malachite green

Explanation:

  • Albert's stain causes the metachromatic granules of Corynebacterium diphtheriae to appear bluish-purple upon staining.

Type

Components

Function

Albert Solution 1
  • Malachite Green for organism staining
  • Toluidine Blue for metachromatic staining
  • Enhances contrast and specificity in staining.

Albert Solution 2
  • Iodine
  • Specifically targets volutin or Babes-Ernst granules.

Procedure:

  • Stain the smear with Albert I stain, then drain and wash it
  • Apply Albert II stain to cover the smear, then drain it

Application:

  • Corynebacterium diphtheriae are slender bacilli arranged in V or L shapes, characterized by metachromatic granules (polar bodies, volutin, or Babes-Ernst granules) at the poles of the bacilli
  • Albert's, Neisser's, and Ponder's stains help stain these distinctive granules in the bacteria
  • These granules are also Found in Spirillum, Gardnerella, Yersinia pestis, yeast, and Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB)

Incorrect Optioins:

Carbol fuchsin and methylene blue (Option B): This combination is used in Ziehl-Neelsen staining for acid-fast bacteria like Mycobacterium tuberculosis, not for Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Carbol fuchsin and malachite green (Option C): Carbol fuchsin is used for acid-fast staining, while malachite green is commonly used in spore staining (e.g., Schaeffer-Fulton method).

Toluidine blue and methylene blue (Option D): While Toluidine blue is a component of Albert’s stain, methylene blue is not. Methylene blue is used in Loeffler’s methylene blue stain.

questions.text: A child presents to the OPD with a swollen, red knee joint that is tender to touch. Two weeks prior, he had an episode of fever with bloody diarrhea. Which of the following could be the possible organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Shigella

Explanation:

  • Shigella species, particularly Shigella flexneri, can trigger reactive arthritis (Reiter's syndrome) in genetically susceptible individuals (especially those with HLA-B27). The arthritis typically develops 1-3 weeks after the initial infection and involves large joints like the knee.

Shigella

Features of Shigella
  • Pathogenic Species
    • Shigella dysenteriae
    • Shigella flexneri
    • Shigella boydii
    • Shigella sonnei
  • Transmission
    • Primarily via the fecal-oral route.
    • Commonly spread through contaminated food and water or direct person-to-person contact.
  • Infective Dose
    • Very low; as few as 10-100 bacteria can cause infection.
  • Invasion
    • Invades and multiplies within colonic epithelial cells, leading to cell death and inflammation.

Clinical Presentation of Shigella:
  • Diarrhea:
    • Typically acute and often bloody (dysentery).
    • Incubation Period: 1-3 days after exposure.
    • Prodromal Period: 1-2 days after the incubation period.
  • Abdominal Pain:
    • Severe cramping.
  • Fever:
    • Often high-grade.
  • Tenesmus:
    • Painful straining with defecation.
  • Systemic Symptoms:
    • Malaise, headache, and sometimes vomiting.
  • Complications
    • Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS): Particularly associated with Shigella dysenteriae type 1.
    • Reactive Arthritis: More commonly seen after infection with Shigella flexneri.
    • Neurological Complications: Including seizures, especially in young children.

Diagnosis

Clinical Evaluation:

  • Based on symptoms such as bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever, along with a recent history of exposure (e.g., travel to endemic areas).

Laboratory Tests:

  • Stool Culture: Gold standard for diagnosis; Shigella species identified on selective media like MacConkey agar or XLD (xylose lysine deoxycholate) agar.
  • Biochemical Tests: Confirmatory tests include lactose non-fermentation and indole production, among other specific biochemical characteristics.
  • Serotyping: Identification of specific Shigella species and serotypes using agglutination tests with specific antisera.
  • PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction): Rapid detection of Shigella-specific genes and virulence factors.
  • Stool Microscopy: Presence of leukocytes and erythrocytes in stool samples indicative of invasive diarrhea.

Treatment

Fluid Replacement:

  • Oral Rehydration Therapy (ORT): Recommended for mild to moderate dehydration.
  • Intravenous Fluids: Necessary for severe dehydration or if the patient cannot tolerate oral fluids.

Antibiotic Therapy:

  • Recommended for severe cases, young children, the elderly, and immunocompromised patients.
  • First-line Antibiotics: Include fluoroquinolones (e.g., ciprofloxacin), third-generation cephalosporins (e.g., ceftriaxone), or azithromycin based on susceptibility testing.
  • Increasing antibiotic resistance necessitates periodic updates on local resistance patterns.

Symptomatic Treatment:

  • Antipyretics for managing fever.
  • Avoidance of antimotility agents like loperamide, which can worsen the infection.

Incorrect Options:

E. coli (Option A): Certain E. coli strains, particularly Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC and Enteroinvasive E. coli (EIEC), can cause bloody diarrhea. However, E. coli is not a common trigger for reactive arthritis, which is a post-infectious immune-mediated condition affecting joints.

Giardia (Option C): Giardia lamblia causes non-bloody, watery diarrhea due to malabsorption but does not typically trigger reactive arthritis.

Rotavirus (Option D): Rotavirus is a leading cause of viral gastroenteritis in children, causing watery diarrhea and dehydration, but it does not cause bloody diarrhea or reactive arthritis.

questions.text: Pneumonia due to a gram-negative pleomorphic bacillus that grows on chocolate agar and is catalase and oxidase-positive is caused by:

questions.text: Which of the following statements about scrub typhus is incorrect?

choices.text: Produces NLF (non-lactose fermenting) colonies on MacConkey agar

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Produces NLF (non-lactose fermenting) colonies on MacConkey agar

Explanation:

Orientia tsutsugamushi is an obligate intracellular bacterium and does not grow on MacConkey agar or any other artificial media.

  • It requires cell culture or animal models for growth.
  • Hence, it does not produce non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar.

The Weil-Felix reaction seen in the case of scrub typhus is only OX K+ antibodies.

  • Weil–Felix Test is a heterophile agglutination test that works on the principle of rickettsial antibodies showing antigenic cross reactivity with Proteus antigens(OX 19, OX 2 and OX K strains).
  • It is a tube agglutination test where serial dilutions of a patient's serum are treated with non-motile strains of P. vulgaris OX 19 and OX 2 and P. mirabilis OX K.

Scrub typhus

Causative agent

Orientia tsutsugamushi - It differs from Rickettsia both genetically and by its cell wall composition i.e. it lacks lipopolysaccharide layer.

Vector

  • Chiggers (larvae of trombiculid mite) (Option A ruled out)

Pathophysiology
  • Scrub typhus is so named because it occurs in areas of scrub vegetation i.e. low lying trees and bushes.
  • It is transmitted by the bite of infected trombiculid mites.
  • Among all stages of mite, the larvae (called chiggers) are the only stage that feed on humans. Hence, scrub typhus is also called chiggerosis.
  • Mites can maintain the organisms through transovarial transmission.
  • Orientia tsutsugamushi infects mononuclear cells but still produces fever and rash.

Clinical features

  • The classic presentation of scrub typhus consists of triad of an eschar (at the site of bite), regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash sparing palms and soles. (Option B ruled out)
  • Non-specific manifestations may appear early such as fever, headache, myalgia, cough, and gastrointestinal symptoms.
  • Complications such as encephalitis and interstitial pneumonia may occur rarely in the late stage (due to vascular injury).

Investigations

  • The Weil-Felix test shows OX K+ only.

Treatment

  • Doxycycline is the drug choice.
  • Azithromycin is given alternatively and the drug of choice in children and pregnant women.

 

Man is an accidental host (Option D)

  • The natural reservoir includes rodents and mites.
  • Humans are accidental hosts when they enter mite-infested areas.

  • Ceftriaxone or Cefotaxime: First-line treatment for suspected bacterial meningitis, including Neisseria meningitidis.
  • Vancomycin: Added to cover potential penicillin-resistant Streptococcus pneumoniae until pathogen identification.
  • Ampicillin: Added if Listeria monocytogenes is suspected, particularly in immunocompromised patients and the elderly.

Definitive Therapy
  • Penicillin G: First choice for confirmed Neisseria meningitidis, given intravenously.
  • Alternative Antibiotics: Continue Ceftriaxone or Cefotaxime if pathogen is susceptible.
  • Duration: Typically lasts 7 days.
  • Dexamethasone: May be used to reduce inflammation and neurological complications, especially if started before or with the first antibiotic dose.

Chemoprophylaxis for Close Contacts
  • Rifampin: 600 mg every 12 hours for 2 days (adults); 10 mg/kg every 12 hours for 2 days (children).
  • Ciprofloxacin: Single dose of 500 mg (adults); not typically used in children.
  • Ceftriaxone: Single intramuscular dose of 250 mg (adults) or 125 mg (children).

Vaccination Prophylaxis
  • Meningococcal polysaccharide vaccines (serogroups A, C, Y, W135): 2 doses for children aged 3-18 months or a single dose for older children and adults.
  • Not given to children less than 2-3 years of age.

Indications for Vaccination

  • Splenic dysfunction
  • Terminal complement component deficiency
  • International travelers
