questions.text: What is the likely pathogen responsible for an 8-year-old boy's continuous diarrhea, starting 20 hours ago, which is rice watery in consistency, causing drowsiness, unresponsiveness, sunken eyes, and poor skin turgor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Vibrio cholera

Explanation:

Given the description of the symptoms—continuous rice-water diarrhea, drowsiness, unresponsiveness, sunken eyes, and poor skin turgor—these are classic signs of cholera, which is caused by Vibrio cholera. Cholera often leads to severe dehydration due to the massive loss of fluid in the form of rice-water stools. The signs of dehydration, such as drowsiness, sunken eyes, and poor skin turgor, indicate the severity of fluid loss.

Pathogenesis

  • Natural Host: Only humans.
  • Transmission: Orally through contaminated water or food.
  • Incubation Period: 1-5 days.

Mechanism of Action

  • Mucus Crossing: Hemagglutinin-protease cleaves mucus and fibronectin.
  • Epithelial Adhesion: Toxin coregulated pilus (TCP) helps the bacteria adhere to the epithelial surface without invading or damaging cells, remaining attached throughout the infection.

Enterotoxin

  • Structure: Consists of one A (active) subunit and five B (binding) subunits.
  • Dissociation in Enterocytes:
    • A subunit splits into A1 and A2 fragments.
    • A1 Fragment Action: Activates cellular adenylate cyclase, leading to increased cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels. This results in an outflow of large quantities of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen, causing watery diarrhea.
  • Receptor Binding: B subunits attach to GM1 ganglioside receptors on the surface of jejunal epithelial cells.

Clinical Features

  • Stool Characteristics: "Rice water" stools with a mild sweet odor.
  • Diarrhea Progression: Initially mild diarrhea and vomiting, rapidly progressing to sudden massive diarrhea.
  • Electrolyte Imbalance: Hypokalemia, base-deficit acidosis.
  • Shock: Due to fluid loss and electrolyte imbalance.

Complications

  • Muscular Cramps
  • Renal Failure
  • Pulmonary Edema
  • Cardiac Arrhythmias
  • Paralytic Ileus

Entamoeba coli (Option B): This is a non-pathogenic amoeba that is usually asymptomatic and does not typically cause such severe diarrhea. Entamoeba histolytica can cause dysentery, but it doesn't present with rice-water stools or the severe dehydration seen in cholera.

Escherichia coli (Option C): Certain strains of E. coli, like Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC), can cause watery diarrhea, but it is generally not as severe as the diarrhea caused by cholera, nor does it typically lead to the extreme dehydration described here.

Shigella sonnei (Option D): Shigella causes dysentery, which typically involves bloody diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and fever, but not rice-water stools or the extreme dehydration seen with cholera

questions.text: A 34-year-old HIV-positive male presented with low-grade fever, cough, night sweats, and weight loss for the past 3 weeks. In view of TB investigations, the Mantoux test was negative; chest X-ray showed non-specific findings, and an adequate amount of sputum could not be collected for slide examination. Which of the following is used to diagnose latent TB infection in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Interferon-gamma release assay

Explanation:

The primary use of IGRAs is to identify individuals with latent tuberculosis infection (LTBI). Tuberculin Skin Test (TST) and Interferon-gamma Release Assays (IGRAs) are specific for latent tuberculosis infection.

Diagnostic Tests:

  • Tuberculin Skin Test (TST)
  • Interferon-gamma Release Assays (IGRAs)
  • Chest X-ray
  • Sputum Tests
  • Biopsy of suspicious lesions or lymph nodes for histopathological examination.

Interferon-gamma Release Assay (IGRA):

  • Principle: T-lymphocytes release interferon-gamma when exposed to M. tuberculosis antigens. Mycobacterium TB antigen CFP10 is used in the test, and it reacts with the patient's T cells to release γ interferons.
  • IGRAs like QuantiFERON-TB Gold In-Tube offer several advantages for LTBI diagnosis:
    • Higher specificity in BCG-vaccinated individuals (negative in BCG-vaccinated individuals)
    • No cross-reactivity with most non-tuberculous mycobacteria
    • Requires only a single patient visit
    • Results are available within 24-48 hours
    • No boosting effect with repeated testing
      • T spot TB Test is also approved in IGRA.

TB lab investigations:

Investigations

Purpose

Advantages

Limitations

Sputum smear

  • Initial screening for pulmonary TB.
  • Samples are stained using the Ziehl-Neelsen method or Auramine-O stain to visualize acid-fast bacilli (AFB) under a microscope.
  • Quick and inexpensive. Can provide results within a few hours.
  • Low sensitivity, especially in cases of extrapulmonary TB or in patients with HIV.
  • Cannot differentiate between Mycobacterium tuberculosis and non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM).

Culture Methods
  • Confirm the diagnosis of TB and assess drug susceptibility.
  • Solid Media: Sputum is inoculated onto solid culture media like Löwenstein-Jensen or Middlebrook agar.
  • Liquid Media: Automated systems like BACTEC or MGIT are used to detect growth faster.
  • The gold standard for TB diagnosis.
  • Allows for drug susceptibility testing.
  • Time-consuming; results can take weeks.
  • Requires specialized laboratory facilities.

Xpert MTB/RIF
  • Detects Mycobacterium tuberculosis and rifampicin resistance.
  • Method:
  • A cartridge-based system that performs nucleic acid amplification (NAAT).
  • Sputum or other specimens are processed directly in the cartridge.
  • Rapid results (within 2 hours).
  • High sensitivity and specificity.
  • Simultaneously detects rifampicin resistance.
  • More expensive than smear microscopy.
  • Does not provide full drug susceptibility testing.

LAMP (Loop-Mediated Isothermal Amplification)
  • Detects DNA of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • Method:
  • Amplifies DNA at a constant temperature without the need for thermal cycling.
  • Sputum or other specimens are used.
  • Rapid results (within 1-2 hours).
  • High specificity and sensitivity.
  • Can be performed at the point of care.
  • Used for patients with HIV with CD4+ counts of less than 100 cells/μL irrespective of signs and symptoms of TB.
  • Less widely available than PCR-based tests.
  • Cannot detect drug resistance directly.

TrueNat
  • Point-of-care test for TB detection.
  • Method:
  • Uses a micro-PCR technology to amplify DNA.
  • Results are available within 60 minutes.
  • Portable and easy to use in peripheral health facilities.
  • Provides results quickly, facilitating immediate treatment decisions.
  

Line Probe Assay (LPA)
  • Detects TB and drug resistance (rifampicin and isoniazid).
  • Method:
    • Sputum samples are processed, and DNA is extracted.
    • Amplified DNA is hybridized to specific probes on a membrane strip.
  • Rapid results (within 1-2 days).
  • Can detect multiple mutations associated with drug resistance.
  • Requires a laboratory setup and trained personnel.
  • Not suitable for all strains of TB.

RFLP
  • IS6110 restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) analysis is widely used for molecular epidemiological studies of tuberculosis.
  • Restriction enzymes Nru I, EcoN I, Pst I, and Pvu II were used to analyze IS6110 fingerprints in Mycobacterium tuberculosis strains H37Rv (virulent) and H37Ra (avirulent).

CBNAAT (Option A) (Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test): This is primarily used for active TB diagnosis and detecting drug-resistant TB by detecting TB DNA in sputum or other body fluids, but it’s not used to diagnose latent TB.

MGIT system (Option B) (Mycobacteria Growth Indicator Tube): This is a culture-based method used for detecting active TB by growing mycobacteria from sputum or other clinical samples. It’s not used for diagnosing latent TB.

Line probe assay (Option D): This is used to detect drug resistance in active TB by identifying mutations in the TB genome, not for diagnosing latent TB.

questions.text: Which of the following is the mechanism of action of cholera toxin?

choices.text: Toxin causes increased guanyl cyclase activity

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Activates adenylate cyclase

Explanation:

Cholera toxin binds to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on intestinal epithelial cells. Once internalized, the A subunit of the toxin activates adenylate cyclase, leading to an increase in cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels. Elevated cAMP disrupts ion transport, causing a significant efflux of chloride ions and water into the intestinal lumen, resulting in profuse watery diarrhea.

Pathogenesis

  • Natural Host: Only humans.
  • Transmission: Orally through contaminated water or food.
  • Incubation Period: 1-5 days.

Mechanism of Action

  • Mucus Crossing: Hemagglutinin-protease cleaves mucus and fibronectin.
  • Epithelial Adhesion: Toxin coregulated pilus (TCP) helps the bacteria adhere to the epithelial surface without invading or damaging cells, remaining attached throughout the infection.

Enterotoxin

  • Structure: Consists of one A (active) subunit and five B (binding) subunits.
  • Dissociation in Enterocytes:
    • A subunit splits into A1 and A2 fragments.
    • A1 Fragment Action: Activates cellular adenylate cyclase, leading to increased cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels. This results in an outflow of large quantities of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen, causing watery diarrhea. (Option B)
  • Receptor Binding: B subunits attach to GM1 ganglioside receptors on the surface of jejunal epithelial cells.

Clinical Features

  • Stool Characteristics: "Rice water" stools with a mild sweet odor.
  • Diarrhea Progression: Initially mild diarrhea and vomiting, rapidly progressing to sudden massive diarrhea.
  • Electrolyte Imbalance: Hypokalemia, base-deficit acidosis.
  • Shock: Due to fluid loss and electrolyte imbalance.

Complications

  • Muscular Cramps
  • Renal Failure
  • Pulmonary Edema
  • Cardiac Arrhythmias
  • Paralytic Ileus

Inhibit elongation factor -2 (Option A): This is the mechanism of diphtheria toxin, not cholera toxin. Diphtheria toxin inhibits protein synthesis by modifying elongation factor-2.

Toxin causes increased guanylate cyclase activity (Option B): This is associated with guanylin or heat-stable enterotoxins (like those produced by some strains of E. coli), but not cholera toxin.

Inhibit 60S subunit (Option D): This mechanism is seen in shiga toxin (produced by Shigella and some strains of E. coli), which inhibits protein synthesis by targeting the 60S ribosomal subunit.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with complaints of fever and sore throat. On examination, he has extensive cervical swelling and a well-demarcated white-gray exudative substance adherent to his oropharynx and attempts to remove this membrane result in bleeding. The parents report that all his childhood vaccines were skipped due to religious beliefs. A throat swab under Albert's staining is as below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Diphtheria

Explanation:

Diphtheria is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae, and it often presents with symptoms like fever, sore throat, and cervical swelling (often referred to as "bull neck"). A key feature is the presence of a well-demarcated, white-gray exudative membrane in the oropharynx, which is adherent and causes bleeding when attempts are made to remove it. This membrane is a hallmark of diphtheria. The fact that the child’s vaccines were skipped increases the risk for this disease, as diphtheria is preventable through vaccination (DPT).

The throat swab showing characteristic Albert's staining would demonstrate the club-shaped, gram-positive bacilli typical of Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Diphtheria

Clinical Features

Complications
  • Sore throat
  • Difficulty swallowing (dysphagia)
  • Low-grade fever
  • Grey Pseudomembrane formation in the throat that bleeds on removal
  • Non-healing ulcers covered by grey membrane on the skin
  • Myocarditis
  • Neurological complications (e.g., paralysis, neuropathy)
  • Renal failure
  • Airway obstruction

 

Culture Media

Colony appearance

Evaluation

  • Small
  • Circular opaque disks
  • Glistening,
  • White with a yellow tinge
  • Advantage: Growth can be detected as early as 6–8 hours.
  • The best medium for metachromatic granule production
  • Disadvantage: Supports the growth of other throat commensals also

(McLeod’s and Hoyle’s-modified PTA)
  • Grey or black colour
  • Advantage: Throat commensals are inhibited
  • Disadvantage: Colonies appear only after 48 hours of incubation

  • Small

  • Sometimes hemolytic(mitis biotype)
  • Differentiate colonies from streptococcal or staphylococcal pharyngitis, which may simulate diphtheria.
  • The serum slope may show growth in 4-8 hours but, if negative, will have to be incubated for 24 hours

Albert Stain

Principle: Albert's stain causes the metachromatic granules of C. diphtheriae to appear bluish-purple upon staining.

  • Corynebacterium diphtheria shows chinese letter/ cuneiform appearance
  • Diphtheroids show regular and palisading appearance with lesser number of granules

 

Type

Components

Function

Albert Solution 1
  • Malachite Green for organism staining
  • Toluidine Blue for metachromatic staining
  • Enhances contrast and specificity in staining.

Albert Solution 2

Procedure:

  1. Stain the smear with Albert I stain, then drain and wash it.
  2. Apply Albert II stain to cover the smear, then drain it.

Application:

  • Corynebacterium diphtheriae are slender bacilli arranged in V or L shapes, characterized by metachromatic granules (polar bodies, volutin, or Babes-Ernst granules) at the poles of the bacilli.
  • Albert's, Neisser's, and Ponder's stains help stain these distinctive granules in the bacteria.

questions.text: Yaws is caused by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - T. Pertunae

Explanation:

Yaws is a chronic infectious disease caused by the bacterium Treponema pertenue, which is a subspecies of the Treponema genus. It primarily affects the skin, bones, and joints and is transmitted through direct, non-sexual contact with the lesions of an infected person, commonly in tropical regions.

Treponema is a genus of spiral-shaped bacteria that are pathogenic to humans.

Spirochetes are spiral hair-like organisms. They are classified as follows.

Shape- Treponemes are corkscrew-shaped cells 6 to 15 μm long and 0.1 to 0.2 μm wide.

Structure- Treponemes have an outer membrane, a peptidoglycan-cytoplasmic membrane complex, and a protoplasmic cylinder.

Movement: Treponemes have flagella that extend from motors at the pole, producing undulating movement through fluids: corkscrew motility.

  • Treponema pallidum: The causative organism of Venereal syphilis. It is generally acquired by close sexual contact.

  • Treponema carateum: Causes pinta. It is acquired via skin-to-skin contact. (Option C ruled out)

  • Treponema refringens- Normal GUT flora- Noguchi’s strain

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy developed bloody diarrhea and abdominal cramps. The bacteria isolated from the stool specimen was non motile and did not ferment lactose or mannitol. Which of the following organisms is implicated here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Shigella dysenteriae

Explanation:

Shigella dysenteriae is a key pathogen that can cause bloody diarrhea and abdominal cramps, typical of shigellosis. This organism is non-motile, does not ferment lactose or mannitol, and typically produces bloody diarrhea due to the invasion of the intestinal mucosa and resulting ulceration.

Clinical Presentation of Shigella:

Diarrhea:

  • Typically acute and often bloody (dysentery).
  • Incubation Period: 1-3 days after exposure.
  • Prodromal Period: 1-2 days after the incubation period.

Abdominal Pain:

  • Severe cramping.

Fever:

  • Often high-grade.

Tenesmus:

  • Painful straining with defecation.

Systemic Symptoms:

  • Malaise, headache, and sometimes vomiting.

Complications

  • Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS): Particularly associated with Shigella dysenteriae type 1.
  • Reactive Arthritis: More commonly seen after infection with Shigella flexneri.
  • Neurological Complications: Including seizures, especially in young children.

Diagnosis

Clinical Evaluation:

  • Based on symptoms such as bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever, along with a recent history of exposure (e.g., travel to endemic areas).

Laboratory Tests:

  • Stool Culture: Gold standard for diagnosis; Shigella species identified on selective media like MacConkey agar or XLD (xylose lysine deoxycholate) agar.
  • Biochemical Tests: Confirmatory tests include lactose non-fermentation and indole production, among other specific biochemical characteristics.
  • Serotyping: Identification of specific Shigella species and serotypes using agglutination tests with specific antisera.
  • PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction): Rapid detection of Shigella-specific genes and virulence factors.
  • Stool Microscopy: Presence of leukocytes and erythrocytes in stool samples indicative of invasive diarrhea.

Treatment

Fluid Replacement:

  • Oral Rehydration Therapy (ORT): Recommended for mild to moderate dehydration.
  • Intravenous Fluids: Necessary for severe dehydration or if the patient cannot tolerate oral fluids.

Antibiotic Therapy:

  • Recommended for severe cases, young children, the elderly, and immunocompromised patients.
  • First-line Antibiotics: Include fluoroquinolones (e.g., ciprofloxacin), third-generation cephalosporins (e.g., ceftriaxone), or azithromycin based on susceptibility testing.
  • Increasing antibiotic resistance necessitates periodic updates on local resistance patterns.

Symptomatic Treatment:

  • Antipyretics for managing fever.
  • Avoidance of antimotility agents like loperamide, which can worsen the infection.

Incorrect Options:

E. coli (Option B): While E. coli (especially E. coli O157:H7) can cause bloody diarrhea, it is lactose fermenting and typically motile. Furthermore, E. coli infections are associated with hemorrhagic colitis and may present with hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) in severe cases. The stool culture results indicating non-motility and no lactose or mannitol fermentation are not typical of E. coli.

Salmonella (Option C): Salmonella species can cause gastroenteritis with bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain. However, Salmonella is typically motile and lactose non-fermenting, so it could appear similar to Shigella, but it typically presents with non-bloody diarrhea in many cases and a longer incubation period.

Shigella sonnei (Option D): Like Shigella dysenteriae, Shigella sonnei can cause bloody diarrhea but is often less virulent and typically produces a milder infection. While it is non-motile and lactose non-fermenting, the severity of symptoms with Shigella sonnei usually doesn't match that of Shigella dysenteriae, which is often associated with more severe disease like dysentery.

questions.text: What are common causes of granuloma formation?
questions.solution:
Correct option A

  • A) Mycobacterial infections: This is correct. Mycobacterial infections, such as tuberculosis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, are well-known for inducing granulomatous inflammation.

Incorrect options

Option B) Viral infections: This is generally incorrect. Viral infections are not typically associated with granuloma formation. Granulomas are more commonly seen in response to certain bacterial and fungal infections.

Option C: Actinomycosis:Can cause granuloma formation but it is not the most common cause.

Option D) Allergic reactions: This is generally incorrect. While allergic reactions can cause inflammation, they do not typically lead to the formation of granulomas. Granulomas are more commonly associated with chronic infections and certain non-infectious conditions.

Corynebacterium diphtheriae (Option A) is a gram positive bacterium causing diphtheria and does not require V or X factors for growth. It grows well on selective media like Loeffler’s or tellurite agar, not by satellitism.

Clostridium tetani (Option B) is an anaerobic bacterium that causes tetanus. It doesn't grow well in aerobic environments like blood agar plates used in satellitism tests, and it does not depend on other bacteria for growth factors.

questions.text: The Kanagawa phenomenon observed on Wagatsuma agar is characteristic of which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Vibrio parahaemolyticus

Explanation:

The Kanagawa phenomenon refers to β-hemolysis (clear zone of hemolysis) produced by Vibrio parahaemolyticus on Wagatsuma agar (a type of high salt blood agar).

  • It is an enteropathogenic halophilic vibrio.
  • Food-borne gastroenteritis (most common) occurs following raw or uncooked sea food intake.
  • Features:
    • It grows only in media containing NaCl.
    • TCBS agar: Green colonies with an opaque, raised centre and flat translucent periphery.
    • String test: Positive.
    • It is oxidase, catalase, nitrate, indole and citrate positive.
    • Antigenic components: Somatic 0, capsular K and flagellar H antigens.
    • Shows Kanagawa phenomenon on wagatsuma agar
    • Microscopy: Bipolar safety pin appearance

Vibrio cholerae (Option A) is a Gram-negative, comma-shaped bacterium that causes cholera, a diarrheal illness often associated with contaminated water. It does not show this hemolysis pattern and is not associated with the characteristic reactions on Wagatsuma agar.

Staphylococcus aureus (Option C), a Gram-positive cocci often found in clusters, is responsible for skin abscesses, toxic shock syndrome. While it can cause β-hemolysis on blood agar, it is not associated with the Kanagawa phenomenon.


Burkholderia pseudomallei (Option D) is a Gram-negative rod that causes melioidosis. It primarily affects individuals with underlying conditions, such as diabetes. It does not grow on Wagatsuma agar, nor does it exhibit the Kanagawa phenomenon.

questions.text: A male presents with lesions and a history of unprotected sexual intercourse a few months ago. What is the most appropriate investigation to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Serology

Explanation:

The lesions depicted in the image, along with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse, suggest a diagnosis of Secondary Syphilis, which is best confirmed through serological testing.

  • It is the second stage of syphilis, which occurs if primary syphilis is left untreated.
  • It presents a few weeks to several months after the initial chancre has healed.
  • It is marked by systemic manifestations and can affect multiple organ systems.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Diffuse, non-pruritic rash, often reddish-brown macules or papules, that is polymorphous and non-vesicular.
    • Mucous membrane lesions, such as condylomata lata, appear in moist areas like the oral cavity and genitals and are highly infectious.
    • Oral signs may include mucous patches or snail track ulcers.
    • “Moth-eaten" alopecia: A patchy, non-scarring hair loss.
    • Buschke-Ollendorff sign: Deep tenderness over lesions.
    • Painless generalized lymphadenopathy (especially epitrochlear nodes)l.
    • Systemic symptoms include fever, malaise, and fatigue, with rare cases showing neurological or ocular involvement.
  • Diagnosis: By serological testing: (Option A)
    • Non-Treponemal Tests:
      • RPR (Rapid Plasma Reagin) and VDRL (Venereal Disease Research Laboratory) are used for screening.
      • These tests detect nonspecific antibodies and can be positive in other conditions.
    • Treponemal Tests:
      • FTA-ABS (Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption) confirms the diagnosis by detecting antibodies specific to Treponema pallidum.
  • Treatment:
    • Standard treatment: Benzathine penicillin G.
    • Dosage: 2.4 million units intramuscularly in a single dose.
    • For those allergic to penicillin, alternatives such as doxycycline or tetracycline can be used.
  • Complications: If left untreated, secondary syphilis can progress to the latent stage and eventually tertiary syphilis, which can lead to serious complications, including cardiovascular, neurological, and systemic damage.

Tzanck smear (Option B) is a diagnostic test primarily used for identifying infections caused by Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) and Varicella-Zoster Virus. It involves examining cells scraped from a lesion under a microscope. However, this test has no role in diagnosing syphilis, as it does not detect Treponema pallidum, the bacterium responsible for the disease.

KOH preparation (Option C) is commonly employed to diagnose superficial fungal infections such as dermatophytosis or candidiasis. A sample from the skin, hair, or nails is treated with potassium hydroxide, which dissolves keratin and allows for the visualization of fungal elements under a microscope. Since syphilis is a bacterial infection, this test is irrelevant in its diagnosis.


Biopsy (Option D) is used to evaluate suspicious skin lesions when the diagnosis is unclear, and it can sometimes reveal histopathological features suggestive of syphilis. It is invasive and nonspecific, whereas serological tests are more sensitive, specific, and the preferred method for diagnosing secondary syphilis.

Which of the following are true statements:

Explanation:

  2. Weil-Felix is a heterophile agglutination test used for Rickettsial infections including Typhus.

questions.text: Chocolate agar is primarily used for the isolation of which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Haemophilus influenzae

Explanation:

The organism described in the question is Haemophilus influenzae.

  • Haemophilus influenzae requires both X (hemin) and V (NAD) factors for growth which is found in chocolate agar.
  • The type b capsular polysaccharide (polyribosylribitol phosphate or PRP) is the most virulent serotype, particularly in unvaccinated children under 5 years old, often causing invasive diseases like meningitis.

Clinical features:

  • Meningitis: Fever, irritability, neck stiffness
  • Other invasive diseases: Epiglottitis, pneumonia, septic arthritis
  • Nontypeable strains often cause mucosal infections like otitis media, sinusitis

Diagnosis:

  • CSF analysis in meningitis: elevated protein, low glucose, pleocytosis
  • Gram stain: small gram-negative coccobacilli
  • Culture on chocolate agar
  • Antigen detection tests (latex agglutination) for rapid diagnosis
  • PCR for definitive identification and serotyping

Treatment:

  • Empiric therapy: Third-generation cephalosporins (ceftriaxone or cefotaxime)
  • Alternative: Chloramphenicol (if cephalosporin allergy)
  • Duration: Usually 10 days for meningitis

Listeria monocytogenes (Option B): Grows on standard blood agar; doesn’t require X or V factors.

Streptococcus pneumoniae (Option C): Best grown on regular blood agar; requires enriched CO₂ but not heated RBCs.

E. coli (Option D): While gram-negative, E. coli is a lactose fermenter on MacConkey agar, not chocolate agar. It is catalase-positive, but oxidase-negative.

questions.text: A farmer presents with fever, malaise, and diarrhea. There is a history of exposure to livestock. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for the illness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Coxiella burnetii

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario of a farmer with acute febrile illness after exposure to livestock suggests the diagnosis of Q fever, a zoonotic infection caused by Coxiella burnetii.
  • Source → Infected livestock (cattle, sheep, goats) — bacteria found in birth products, urine, faeces, and milk.
  • Transmission → Inhalation of aerosolized particles (often from contaminated hay, barn dust, or animal waste).
  • Symptoms → Fever, malaise, myalgia, headache; may include pneumonia or hepatitis.
  • Gastrointestinal symptoms like diarrhoea can occur, especially in acute infection.
  • No rash (unlike many other rickettsial infections).

Rickettsia rickettsii (Option A): Rocky Mountain spotted fever; requires tick bite; classic triad is fever, rash and history of tick exposure.

Rickettsia typhi (Option B): Murine (endemic) typhus; transmitted by fleas from rodents, not livestock.

Orientia tsutsugamushi (Option D): Scrub typhus; transmitted by chigger mites; seen in rural/forest scrub areas, not directly from livestock.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever after returning from a forest trip. On examination, a black eschar is noted on the abdomen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis and its drug of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Doxycycline

Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with fever and a black eschar (site of the bite) after a forest trip is suggestive of mild to moderate Scrub Typhus in which Doxycycline is given.

 

Scrub typhus

Causative agent

Orientia tsutsugamushi (bacteria)

Transmission

Chiggers (larval mites)

Vector

Trombiculid mite (Leptotrombidium)

Geographical distribution

Endemic in the “tsutsugamushi triangle” (parts of Asia, Australia, Pacific Islands).

Clinical manifestations

Fever, headache, muscle pain, eschar (dark, scab-like lesion at the site of bite), and lymphadenopathy.

Diagnosis

Serological tests (ELISA, immunofluorescence) and molecular methods (PCR).

Treatment

Antibiotics (Doxycycline, Azithromycin)

Prevention

Avoid mite-infested areas, wearing protective clothing, and using insect repellants.

Complications

Organ failure, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), neurological complications.

Penicillin (Option A): Not effective against rickettsial organisms.

Ceftriaxone (Option C): Used for bacterial meningitis, typhoid, gonorrhea, not scrub typhus.

Artesunate (Option D): Antimalarial; used for severe Plasmodium falciparum malaria.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man develops profuse vomiting and diarrhea within 3 hours of consuming pre-packaged salad and milk at a picnic. There is no fever. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Staphylococcus aureus

Explanation:

  • The very short incubation period (1–6 hours) after food ingestion, combined with the absence of fever and the involvement of dairy/salad-type foods, points strongly to preformed, heat-stable enterotoxins of Staphylococcus aureus.
  • S. aureus produces enterotoxins (types A, B, C, D, E) that are resistant to heat and gastric enzymes, leading to sudden-onset nausea, vomiting, and sometimes diarrhea.
  • Because illness is due to ingestion of toxin (not bacterial multiplication in the body), symptoms appear rapidly and resolve within 24–48 hours.

Clostridium perfringens (Option A): Causes a toxin-mediated diarrheal illness but incubation is longer (usually 8–16 h) and linked to reheated meat/gravies.

Salmonella enterica (Option B): Typically causes invasive gastroenteritis with longer incubation (6–72 h) and fever.

Bacillus cereus (Option D): Has two syndromes - emetic form (short incubation 1–5 h, often linked to chinese food) and diarrheal form (longer).

questions.text: A woman presents with sudden-onset high-grade fever, hypotension, diffuse rash, and a history of using a tampon for an extended period. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Toxic Shock Syndrome

Explanation:

  • This clinical triad (fever, hypotension/shock, diffuse erythrodermic rash with history of tampon use) is most consistent with Toxic Shock Syndrome (TSS) caused by toxin-producing Staphylococcus aureus (TSST-1) or sometimes group A Streptococcus.
  • TSST-1 is a superantigen that triggers massive, non-specific T-cell activation and cytokine release → shock and rash; desquamation of palms/soles later is typical.

Major Criteria (All Required)

  • Acute fever; temperature >38.8° C (101.8° F)
  • Hypotension (orthostatic, shock; blood pressure below age-appropriate norms)
  • Rash (erythroderma with convalescent desquamation)

Minor Criteria (Any 3 or more)

  • Mucous membrane inflammation (vaginal, oropharyngeal or conjunctival hyperemia, strawberry tongue)
  • Vomiting, diarrhea
  • Liver abnormalities (bilirubin or transaminase greater than twice the upper limit of normal)
  • Renal abnormalities (blood urea nitrogen or creatinine greater than twice the upper limit of normal, or greater than 5 white blood cells per high-power field)
  • Muscle abnormalities (myalgia or creatinine phosphokinase greater than twice the upper limit of normal)
  • CNS abnormalities (alteration in consciousness without focal neurologic signs)
  • Thrombocytopenia

Treatment:

  • Supportive - IVFluids +/- Ionotropes
  • One course of Anti-staphylococcal antibiotics

Septic shock (Option A): May cause hypotension and high fever, but TSS has a characteristic diffuse rash and association with tampon/exogenous foreign body and superantigen mechanism.

Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (Option C): Presents with pelvic pain, cervical motion tenderness; systemic hypotension and diffuse rash are not characteristic.

Streptococcal pharyngitis (Option D): Localized sore throat ± fever; not the shock/rash pattern described.

Clostridium tetani (Option B): Causes tetanus (neurotoxin-mediated spastic paralysis).

Clostridium botulinum (Option D): Produces botulinum toxin, causing flaccid paralysis; not gas gangrene.

questions.text: Group A Streptococcus is the most common cause of bacterial pharyngitis in school-aged children. Which of the following bacterial components is primarily responsible for its attachment to fibronectin on the epithelial lining of the pharynx?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lipoteichoic acid

Explanation:

  • Group A Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes) attaches to the epithelial lining of the pharynx using lipoteichoic acid (LTA).
  • LTA is anchored in the bacterial cell membrane and extends through the peptidoglycan layer.
  • It binds to fibronectin on host epithelial cells → facilitates initial colonization.

Incorrect Options:

Lipoprotein (Option A): Found in bacterial membranes; functions mainly in nutrient transport and immune evasion, not primary attachment to fibronectin.

Capsule (Option C): Composed of hyaluronic acid in GAS; helps evade phagocytosis, not for initial adherence.

Flagella (Option D): GAS is non-motile, so it has no flagella.

questions.text: A 25-year-old sewage worker presents with fever for 1 week and weakness for 1 day. Laboratory evaluation reveals elevated bilirubin and decreased urine output. Conjunctival redness? What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Weil's disease

Explanation:

Weil’s disease

  • Cause: Severe form of leptospirosis due to Leptospira interrogans.
  • Transmission: Contact with water or soil contaminated by urine of infected animals (especially rodents).
  • Triad in severe disease:
    1. Jaundice - due to hepatocellular dysfunction.
    2. Renal failure - due to tubulointerstitial nephritis.
    3. Hemorrhagic manifestations - less prominent in this case.
  • Conjunctival suffusion is highly suggestive, especially in early disease.

Brucellosis (Option A): From unpasteurized dairy or livestock; causes undulating fever, hepatosplenomegaly, but jaundice and conjunctival suffusion are uncommon.

Enteric fever (Typhoid) (Option C): Caused by Salmonella Typhi; step-ladder fever, relative bradycardia, abdominal symptoms, no prominent jaundice or conjunctival suffusion.

questions.text: In a village, several people developed dysentery after consuming raw milk. On laboratory examination, gram-negative, curved rods with polymorphonuclear infiltration were found in stool samples. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Campylobacter jejuni

Explanation:

Campylobacter jejuni:

  • Morphology: Gram-negative, curved/spiral rods, motile with polar flagella.
  • Reservoir: GI tract of poultry, cattle; raw milk is a common source.
  • Pathogenesis: Invades intestinal mucosa → causes inflammation and ulceration.
  • Clinical features: Fever, abdominal cramps, bloody diarrhea.
  • Complications: Guillain–Barré syndrome, reactive arthritis.

Incorrect Options:

Clostridium perfringens (Option A): Gram-positive rods; causes watery diarrhea, rarely dysentery.

Staphylococcus aureus (Option B): Gram-positive cocci; preformed toxin → vomiting and watery diarrhea, no PMNs in stool.

Vibrio parahaemolyticus (Option C): Gram-negative curved rods, but linked to seafood, not raw milk, and usually causes watery diarrhea.

questions.text: A patient presents with a history of chronic meningitis. Laboratory findings show Gram-positive, filamentous branching bacteria, Positive ZN stain, and Growth on paraffin bait culture. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Nocardia asteroides

Explanation:

Nocardia:

  • Morphology: Gram-positive, branching, filamentous rods.
  • Acid-fast property: Weakly acid-fast due to mycolic acids in cell wall (detected by modified Ziehl–Neelsen stain).
  • Habitat: Soil organism, opportunistic pathogen.
  • Diseases: Can cause chronic lung disease, brain abscess, and meningitis, especially in immunocompromised patients.
  • Unique culture feature: Grows on paraffin bait medium.

Actinomyces israelii (Option A): Gram-positive branching bacteria but not acid-fast and does not grow on paraffin bait; causes cervicofacial actinomycosis.

Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Option B): Acid-fast bacilli, not branching filamentous bacteria; does not grow on paraffin bait.

Cryptococcus neoformans (Option D): Encapsulated yeast, detected with India ink, not Gram-positive filamentous bacteria.

questions.text: A patient presents with recurrent infections with Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Which of the following investigations is most appropriate to evaluate the underlying immunodeficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Terminal complement (C5–C9) assay

Explanation:

  • Deficiency of the terminal complement pathway (C5–C9) impairs the formation of the membrane attack complex (MAC), which is essential for direct lysis of Neisseria species.
  • Patients remain otherwise immunologically normal but are prone to recurrent, often disseminated infections by Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Neisseria meningitidis.
  • A functional or quantitative assay of C5–C9 confirms the diagnosis.

C1 esterase inhibitor assay is used to diagnose hereditary angioedema, unrelated to infections (Option A).

Quantitative immunoglobulin levels assess antibody-mediated immunity but do not specifically predict susceptibility to Neisseria (Option B).

Nitroblue tetrazolium test diagnoses chronic granulomatous disease by assessing neutrophil oxidative burst, unrelated here (Option C).

questions.text: A farmer presents with an ulcerative skin lesion showing signs of necrosis. Smear from the ulcer stained with polychrome methylene blue reveals capsulated bacilli that are McFadyean reaction positive. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Bacillus anthracis

Explanation:

  • Bacillus anthracis is a Gram-positive, spore-forming rod with a polypeptide capsule made of poly-D-glutamic acid.
  • In McFadyean reaction, the capsule stains purple-pink against a blue background using polychrome methylene blue, which is diagnostic.
  • Cutaneous anthrax typically presents with a painless black eschar surrounded by marked edema (“malignant pustule”) after contact with infected animals or contaminated animal products — common in farmers.

Clostridium perfringens (Option A) causes gas gangrene and does not show a capsule or McFadyean positivity.

Yersinia pestis (Option C) causes plague with bipolar staining and does not test positive for McFadyean reaction .

Francisella tularensis (Option D) causes tularemia but is not identified via McFadyean stain

questions.text: Patient with HIV presenting with bouts of cough and fever. Which medium is appropriate for diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) medium

Explanation: A patient with HIV presenting with cough and fever raises suspicion of tuberculosis (TB), which is common in immunocompromised individuals. Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) medium is a specialized culture medium used to isolate Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Lab Investigations for TB:

Investigations

Purpose

Advantages

Limitations

Sputum smear

  • Initial screening for pulmonary TB.
  • Samples are stained using the Ziehl-Neelsen method or Auramine-O stain to visualize acid-fast bacilli (AFB) under a microscope.
  • Quick and inexpensive. Can provide results within a few hours.
  • Low sensitivity, especially in cases of extrapulmonary TB or in patients with HIV.
  • Cannot differentiate between Mycobacterium tuberculosis and non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM).

Culture Methods
  • Confirm the diagnosis of TB and assess drug susceptibility.
  • Solid Media: Sputum is inoculated onto solid culture media like Löwenstein-Jensen or Middlebrook agar.
  • Liquid Media: Automated systems like BACTEC or MGIT are used to detect growth faster.
  • The gold standard for TB diagnosis.
  • Allows for drug susceptibility testing.
  • Time-consuming; results can take weeks.
  • Requires specialized laboratory facilities.

Xpert MTB/RIF
  • Detects Mycobacterium tuberculosis and rifampicin resistance.
  • Method:
    • A cartridge-based system that performs nucleic acid amplification (NAAT).
    • Sputum or other specimens are processed directly in the cartridge.
  • Rapid results (within 2 hours).
  • High sensitivity and specificity.
  • Simultaneously detects rifampicin resistance.
  • More expensive than smear microscopy.
  • Does not provide full drug susceptibility testing.

LAMP (Loop-Mediated Isothermal Amplification)
  • Detects DNA of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • Method:
    • Amplifies DNA at a constant temperature without the need for thermal cycling.
    • Sputum or other specimens are used.
  • Rapid results (within 1-2 hours).
  • High specificity and sensitivity.
  • Can be performed at the point of care.
  • Used for patients with HIV with CD4+ counts of less than 100 cells/μL irrespective of signs and symptoms of TB.
  • Less widely available than PCR-based tests.
  • Cannot detect drug resistance directly.

TrueNat
  • Point-of-care test for TB detection.
  • Method:
    • Uses a micro-PCR technology to amplify DNA.
    • Results are available within 60 minutes.
  • Portable and easy to use in peripheral health facilities.
  • Provides results quickly, facilitating immediate treatment decisions.
  

Line Probe Assay (LPA)
  • Detects TB and drug resistance (rifampicin and isoniazid).
  • Method:
    • Sputum samples are processed, and DNA is extracted.
    • Amplified DNA is hybridized to specific probes on a membrane strip.
  • Rapid results (within 1-2 days).
  • Can detect multiple mutations associated with drug resistance.
  • Requires a laboratory setup and trained personnel.
  • Not suitable for all strains of TB.

RFLP
  • IS6110 restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) analysis is widely used for molecular epidemiological studies of tuberculosis.
  • Restriction enzymes Nru I, EcoN I, Pst I, and Pvu II were used to analyze IS6110 fingerprints in Mycobacterium tuberculosis strains H37Rv (virulent) and H37Ra (avirulent).

Tinsdale medium (Option A) is used for Corynebacterium diphtheriae, which causes diphtheria.

MacConkey agar (Option C) is used for gram-negative bacteria, particularly enteric pathogens like E. coli and Klebsiella.

Loeffler serum slope (LSS) (Option D) enhances the growth of Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

questions.text: A firefighter was admitted with fever, cough, culture shown in the image reveals gram-negative, oxidase-positive bacilli. Colonies transilluminating while passing under UV light. Choose the correct agent.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pseudomonas aeruginosa

Explanation: The firefighter with fever and cough has a culture showing gram-negative, oxidase-positive bacilli with fluorescent colonies under UV light, which is characteristic of Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

Diagnostic Tests for Pseudomonas aeruginosa:

Diagnostic Method

Description

Specific Features for Pseudomonas aeruginosa

Sample Collection

Collect specimens such as sputum, urine, wound swabs, blood, ear discharge, eye discharge, or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).

Specimens vary based on the site of infection.

Microscopy

Gram stain

Gram-negative rods; motile with flagella.

Culture

Growth on common laboratory media:

Blood agar

Produces beta-hemolytic gray, moist colonies.

MacConkey agar

Produces pale, non-lactose fermenting colonies, Fluorescence under UV light.

Nutrient agar

Produces large, irregular colonies with a metallic sheen.

Peptone water

Forms uniform turbidity with surface pellicle.

Cetrimide Agar

Selective medium that inhibits other Gram-negative bacteria; specifically selected for Pseudomonas aeruginosa; pigment production (e.g., pyocyanin).
 

King’s medium

used to increase pigment production by pseudomonas

Biochemical Tests

Various biochemical tests to identify specific metabolic properties:

Oxidase test

Positive

Catalase test

Positive

ICUT Test:

Indole test

Negative

Citrate test

Positive

Urease test

Negative

Triple sugar test

Shows alkaline slant with no gas and hydrogen sulfide.

Molecular Methods

PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction), 16S rRNA sequencing

Provides specific and sensitive detection of Pseudomonas aeruginosa DNA.

Antimicrobial Susceptibility Testing

Disk diffusion method, Minimum Inhibitory Concentration (MIC) testing

Determines the susceptibility of Pseudomonas aeruginosa to various antibiotics.

Klebsiella (Option A): Although Gram-negative, it is oxidase-negative. It does not produce fluorescent pigments under UV light and typically forms mucoid colonies due to its capsule.
Staphylococcus aureus (Option B) is Gram-positive, whereas the given organism is Gram-negative. It does not produce fluorescent pigments under UV light and forms golden-yellow colonies, not greenish ones.
Serratia (Option D) is Gram-negative and oxidase-negative. Some Serratia species produce red pigment (prodigiosin), but they do not fluoresce under UV light like Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

questions.text: A group of students consumed fried rice in a restaurant. Six hours later, they start vomiting. What is the etiological agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bacillus cereus

Explanation: Bacillus cereus causes rapid-onset vomiting (within 1–6 hours) after consuming contaminated fried rice.

Clinical Features of Bacillus cereus:

Clinical Features

Details


 

Food Poisoning
  • Two distinct forms: diarrhoeal and emetic.
  • Diarrhoeal form: Linked to contaminated meat, poultry, vegetables, and pasta; symptoms appear 8-16 hours post-ingestion.
  • Symptoms: Abdominal pain, diarrhoea (vomiting less common, fever rare)
  • Emetic form: Associated with cooked rice, especially fried rice; nausea and vomiting within 1-6 hours.
  • Some cases may include diarrhoea

Other Infections
  • Opportunistic infections: Ocular infections, meningitis, septicemia, endocarditis, osteomyelitis
  • More common in immunocompromised individuals, intravenous drug users, neonates, and post-surgical patients

Diagnosis of Bacillus cereus:

Diagnostic Method

Details

Food Poisoning
  • Culture of implicated food essential.
  • >105 B. cereus cells per gram confirms the diagnosis.
  • Quantitative stool cultures with at least 105 cells per gram support diagnosis.

Culture Characteristics
  • Aerobic growth at 37°C on sheep blood agar.
  • β-hemolytic colonies with frosted glass appearance.
  • Motile, lecithinase positive, fermenting salicin

Selective Media
  • MYPA aids in isolating B. cereus from faeces and other sources

Microscopy
  • Spore-forming, Gram-positive bacilli.
  • Motile

Clostridium botulinum (Option B) causes botulism, presenting with descending paralysis and no vomiting, with symptoms appearing 12–36 hours after ingestion.

Escherichia coli (Option C): ETEC (Enterotoxigenic E. coli) causes watery diarrhea, not isolated vomiting, and has a longer incubation period (12–72 hours).


Shigella dysenteriae (Option D): Causes bloody diarrhea (dysentery) with fever, not acute vomiting.

questions.text: A farmer presents with fever and subconjunctival hemorrhage. The microscopic agglutination test turns to be positive. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Leptospira

Explanation: A farmer with fever and subconjunctival hemorrhage along with a positive microscopic agglutination test points toward Leptospira infection (Leptospirosis).

Leptospirosis:

Causative Agent

Leptospira interrogans (bacteria)

Transmission
  • Zoonotic disease
  • Indirect: Contact with water, moist soil, or surfaces contaminated with animal urine.
  • Direct: Contact with urine or parturition products from infected animals.

Pathogenesis Phases
  • Septicemic Phase: Entry through mucosa or skin, dissemination via bloodstream to organs.
  • Immune Phase: Antibodies develop, spirochetes disappear from blood; antigen-antibody complexes form, and renal colonization occurs.

Clinical Syndromes
  • Mild Anicteric Illness: Seen in 90% of cases, flu-like symptoms with fever, headache, conjunctival suffusion, nausea, vomiting, and myalgia.
  • Weil’s Disease: Severe icteric illness in 10% of cases; rapid progression, fatality rate of 5-15%.

Culture Media
  • Ellinghausen-McCullough-Johnson-Harris (EMJH) medium is commonly used for culturing Leptospira species showing Dinger’s ring.

​​​​​​​

  • It is a semi-solid or liquid medium that supports the slow-growing leptospires, often requiring incubation for weeks.
  • Specimen Sources: Blood, urine, or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) samples are often used, depending on the stage of infection.
  • Other culture media are Korthoff and Fletcher.

Diagnosis

  • Microscopic Agglutination Test (MAT): Considered the gold standard for Leptospira detection, MAT measures antibodies in serum samples.
  • The Modified Faine’s Criteria used to aid in the diagnosis of leptospirosis, especially in endemic areas.This scoring system combines clinical, epidemiological and laboratory data to increase diagnostic accuracy.
  • PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction): Provides a faster diagnosis by detecting leptospira DNA in blood or urine, especially effective in the early stage.
  • ELISA: Used for antibody detection and is helpful for confirming infection in the later stages.

Treatment

Antibiotics: Early antibiotic therapy is crucial and often involves:

  • Doxycycline: Typically used for mild cases and prophylaxis.
  • Penicillin or Ampicillin: Preferred for severe cases.

Brucella (Option A) causes undulant fever and hepatosplenomegaly but does not cause subconjunctival hemorrhage. The standard test is the serum agglutination test (SAT), not the microscopic agglutination test (MAT).
Escherichia coli (Option C) primarily causes gastrointestinal and urinary tract infections and is not associated with conjunctival hemorrhage, or a positive MAT.
Staphylococcus aureus (Option D) causes skin infections, pneumonia, and endocarditis but does not cause subconjunctival hemorrhage or a positive MAT, which is specific for Leptospira.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man was admitted with a murmur and blood culture positive for Gram-positive cocci. Choose the common agent causing prosthetic valve infective endocarditis.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Staphylococcus epidermidis

Explanation: Staphylococcus epidermidis, a coagulase-negative Staphylococcus (CoNS), is the most common cause of prosthetic valve infective endocarditis.

Prosthetic Valve Endocarditis:

  • It occurs following cardiac valve replacement.
  • Early prosthetic valve endocarditis (occurs within 12 months of valve replacement):
    • Generally nosocomial.
    • Results from intra-operative contamination of the prosthesis or a bacteremic postoperative complication.
    • Common agents: CoNS (e.g., S. epidermidis) and S. aureus.
  • Late prosthetic valve endocarditis (occurs after 12 months of valve replacement):
    • Usually community-acquired.
    • Common agents: Viridans streptococci.
  • Overall:
    • Regardless of the time of onset after surgery, CoNS are the most common agents (at least 68-85%).
    • Majority are methicillin-resistant CoNS.

Streptococcus viridans (Option A) is a common cause of native valve endocarditis, particularly following dental procedures or in patients with pre-existing valvular disease. However, it is not the primary cause of prosthetic valve endocarditis (PVE), where Staphylococcal species predominate.

Staphylococcus aureus (Option C) is a virulent pathogen that causes rapidly progressive (acute) infective endocarditis, affecting both native and prosthetic valves. It is a leading cause of healthcare-associated IE, often seen in intravenous drug users (IVDU) and patients with catheters or implanted devices. While it can cause prosthetic valve IE, it is more common in late-onset cases rather than early PVE.

Enterococci (Option D) (e.g., Enterococcus faecalis) are opportunistic pathogens that cause subacute endocarditis, particularly in elderly patients with genitourinary or gastrointestinal infections. Though they can infect prosthetic valves, they are not the primary causative agent.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, neck rigidity, headache, vomiting, and petechial rashes on the lower limbs. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Neisseria meningitidis

Explanation: The patient's clinical features of fever, neck rigidity, headache, vomiting, and petechial rashes on the lower limbs point toward meningococcal meningitis caused by Neisseria meningitidis.

ClinicalFeatures of Neisseria meningitidis:

  • Rashes: Non-blanching rash (petechial or purpuric) develops in more than 80% of cases.
  • Septicemia:
    • Attributed to endotoxin-induced endothelial injury.
    • Leads to increased vascular permeability and intravascular thrombosis.
  • Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome:
    • Severe form of fulminant meningococcemia.
    • Characterized by large purpuric rashes (purpura fulminans), shock, disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), bilateral adrenal hemorrhage, and multiorgan failure.
  • Pyogenic meningitis:
    • Commonly affects young children (3-5 years of age).
    • Presentation includes fever, vomiting, headache, and neck stiffness.
    • Similar to other bacterial meningitis but with the presence of rashes.
  • Chronic meningococcemia:
    • Rare condition.
    • Characterized by repeated episodes of petechial rashes, fever, arthritis, and splenomegaly.
  • Postmeningococcal reactive disease:
    • Develops 4-10 days later due to immune complexes (capsular antigens and their antibodies).
    • Manifestations include arthritis, rash, iritis, pericarditis, polyserositis, and fever.

Lab Investigations of Neisseria meningitidis:

Investigation

Findings

Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF) Analysis
  • Appearance

Cloudy or purulent
  • White Blood Cell Count (WBC)

Elevated (pleocytosis), typically >1,000 cells/µL, with predominance of neutrophils
  • Protein

Elevated
  • Glucose

Decreased
  • Gram Stain

Presence of gram-negative diplococci
  • Culture

Growth of Neisseria meningitidis on chocolate agar or Thayer-Martin agar
  • Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR)

Detection of Neisseria meningitidis DNA
  • Latex Agglutination Test

Positive for Neisseria meningitidis antigens

Blood Tests
  • Culture

Growth of Neisseria meningitidis
  • White Blood Cell Count

Elevated leukocytosis with left shift

Clostridium perfringens (Option B) causes gas gangrene and food poisoning, not meningitis with petechial rash.

Cryptococcus neoformans (Option C) is typically seen in immunocompromised patients (e.g., HIV) and presents with chronic meningitis without petechial rash.

Clostridium difficile (Option D) causes antibiotic-associated diarrhea and pseudomembranous colitis, not meningitis

questions.text: A patient’s laboratory results were positive for malarial antigen, and the Widal test findings were as follows: O ag >1:300, H ag >1:20, A >1:20, B >1:20. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Recent infection by Salmonella spp

Explanation: A significantly elevated O antigen titer (>1:300) only in the Widal test suggests a recent Salmonella infection.

Widal Test:

  • It is a highly sensitive but poorly specific serological test used to diagnose typhoid fever caused by Salmonella typhi.
  • It detects specific antibodies in the patient's serum that react with the antigens of Salmonella typhi.
  • The test is based on the agglutination reaction where patient serum is mixed with antigens of Salmonella typhi.
  • If the antibodies are present, they will cause the antigens to clump together (agglutinate), indicating a positive result.
  • The test primarily measures:
    • O-antibodies: These are antibodies against the somatic (O) antigens of Salmonella typhi.
    • H-antibodies: These are antibodies against the flagellar (H) antigens of Salmonella typhi.
  • Antigens Used:
    • O antigen of S. Typhi (TO)
    • H antigen of S. Typhi (TH)
    • H antigen of S. Paratyphi A (AH)
    • H antigen of S. Paratyphi B (BH)
  • Interpretation:
    • Cut-off values in most parts of India:
      • H agglutinin titer >200.
      • O agglutinin titer >100.
    • Low titers: Considered baseline in endemic areas and should be ignored.

Widal Test Result

Suggestive of

Rise of TO and TH antibody

Enteric fever due to S. Typhi

Rise of TO and AH antibody

Enteric fever due to S. Paratyphi A

Rise of TO and BH antibody

Enteric fever due to S. Paratyphi B

Rise of only TO antibody

Recent infection due to S. Typhi or S. Paratyphi A or B

Rise of only TH antibody

Convalescent stage / Anamnestic response

Rise of all TH, AH, BH

Post-TAB vaccination antibodies (Option B)

Past infection (Option C): A past infection usually results in elevated H antigen titers, whereas in this case, the O antigen titer is significantly high, indicating a recent infection.

Reconvalescence (Option D): In the recovery phase, both O and H antigen titers decline, whereas in this case, the O antigen titer remains markedly high, supporting a recent infection instead.

questions.text: MOA of botulinum toxin is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Inhibits the release of acetylcholine

Explanation: The mechanism of action of botulinum toxin is inhibition of acetylcholine release at the neuromuscular junction.

Mechanism of Action of Botulinum Toxin:

Botulinum toxin binds to acetylcholine receptors at neuromuscular junctions, preventing the release of acetylcholine, which is essential for muscle contraction. This leads to flaccid paralysis, a hallmark of botulism.

Inhibits Elongation Factor 2 (Option A): This describes the MOA of Diphtheria toxin and Pseudomonas exotoxin A, which inhibit protein synthesis by ADP-ribosylation of Elongation Factor-2 (EF-2), leading to cell death.

Inhibits the release of GABA (Option B): This describes the action of Tetanus toxin, which blocks inhibitory neurotransmitters (GABA and glycine) in the spinal cord, causing spastic paralysis.

Increases cAMP (Option D): Toxins that increase cyclic AMP (cAMP) include cholera toxin and pertussis toxin, which cause fluid secretion (diarrhea) and immune modulation, respectively.

questions.text: A person with the H/o long-term sexual relationship presented with painful ulcers on his genitals with tender lymphadenopathy. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Chancroid

Explanation: The clinical scenario of a person with a history of a long-term sexual relationship presenting with painful ulcers on the genitals and tender lymphadenopathy points towards a diagnosis of Chancroid, typically caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

Haemophilus ducreyi:

  • Gram-negative coccobacillus
  • Fastidious, requiring X factor but not V factor
  • Forms characteristic "school of fish" or "railroad track" arrangements in Gram stains
  • Safety pin appearance of bipolar staining.

  • Clinical features of chancroid:
    • Painful genital ulcers with ragged edges and a purulent base
    • Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes)
    • Incubation period of 3-10 days
  • Diagnosis:
    • Clinical presentation
    • Gram stain of ulcer exudate
    • Culture on selective media (challenging and low sensitivity)
    • PCR (most sensitive method)
    • Differential diagnosis includes syphilis, herpes simplex, and lymphogranuloma venereum
  • Treatment:
    • Azithromycin 1g orally single dose, OR
    • Ceftriaxone 250mg IM single dose, OR
    • Ciprofloxacin 500mg orally twice daily for 3 days, OR
    • Erythromycin 500mg orally three times daily for 7 days
    • Treatment of sexual partners is crucial

Gonorrhea (Option A) typically causes urethritis and discharge, not painful ulcers or lymphadenopathy.

Chlamydia (Option B) can cause urethritis or cervicitis, but ulcers are rare.

Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) (Option C) presents with painless ulcers and later, painful lymphadenopathy, unlike the painful ulcers seen in chancroid.

questions.text: A patient admitted with fever and nuchal rigidity. CSF analysis shows decreased glucose and increased protein and neutrophils. Choose the correct treatment
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ceftriaxone

Explanation:

The clinical scenario of a patient with fever, nuchal rigidity, and CSF findings of decreased glucose, increased protein, and neutrophilic pleocytosis points towards a diagnosis of bacterial meningitis.

Ceftriaxone is the first-line antibiotic for treatment of bacterial meningitis.

Bacterial Meningitis in Adults and Prevention

Causes

Streptococcus pneumoniae and Neisseria meningitides are the primary causes. Listeria monocytogenes is a significant risk in adults over 50, especially in those with diabetes, alcoholism, or weakened immune systems.

Pathophysiological Process

Classic Triad of Symptoms
  • Fever
  • Headache
  • Nuchal rigidity (stiff neck)

CSF Findings
  • Opening pressure: Elevated
  • Predominant cell type: Polymorphonuclear neutrophils (PMNs)
  • Protein: Elevated
  • Glucose: Decreased
  • Gross appearance: Turbid

Treatment
  • Immediate Management:
    • Start with intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover pathogens.
    • First-line antibiotic of choice: Ceftriaxone
    • Treatment is then adjusted based on the identified organism and its susceptibility
  • Adjunctive Therapy: Dexamethasone may be given to reduce inflammation and prevent complications, particularly if administered early.
  • Supportive Care: Manage complications like raised intracranial pressure and seizures.

Prevention
  • Vaccines for H. influenzae type b, N. meningitidis, and S. pneumoniae. No vaccine currently exists for group B meningococcal infections.
  • Chemoprophylaxis: Close contacts of individuals with meningococcal meningitis should receive prophylactic antibiotics like rifampicin, ciprofloxacin, azithromycin or ceftriaxone to reduce the risk of secondary infections.
    • Rifampicin - 600 mg 12 hourly for 2 days
    • Ciprofloxacin - 500 mg single dose
    • Azithromycin 500 mg single dose
    • Ceftriaxone - 250 mg Intramuscular single dose

Ampicillin (Option A) is primarily used in Listeria monocytogenes meningitis, which is more common in neonates, elderly, and immunocompromised patients. It is not first-line for typical bacterial meningitis in healthy adults.

Penicillin (Option C) was historically used for Neisseria meningitidis but is not sufficient as monotherapy due to increasing resistance. Empirical therapy requires broader coverage.

Vancomycin (Option D) is used in combination with Ceftriaxone when penicillin-resistant Streptococcus pneumoniae is suspected, but it is not sufficient alone.

questions.text: KAT G mutation associated with:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Isoniazid

Explanation: The katG mutation causes Isoniazid resistance by preventing its activation inside Mycobacterium tuberculosis, making the drug ineffective.

Mechanisms of Isoniazid Resistance

KatG gene mutation

INH is a prodrug, converted to the active form by catalase-peroxidase produced by the Kat G gene. The mutated catalase enzyme does not form the active drug

KasA gene mutation

Component of cell wall mycolic acid

InhA gene overexpression

Causes cross-resistance to Ethionamide (second-line drug)

Rifampicin (Option B) resistance is associated with mutations in the rpoB gene (RNA polymerase β-subunit), not KAT G.

Levofloxacin (Option C) resistance is linked to mutations in the gyrA and gyrB genes, which encode DNA gyrase, a key enzyme for bacterial DNA replication.

Ethambutol (Option D) resistance is associated with mutations in the embB gene, which affects arabinosyl transferase, an enzyme involved in mycobacterial cell wall synthesis.

questions.text: A traveler with a history of oyster consumption presents with diarrhea, abdominal pain, and vomiting. What is the most likely causative agent?

questions.text: A patient with a history of penicillin allergy has been diagnosed with Enterococcus infective endocarditis. Which of the following antibiotics is the most appropriate treatment option?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Vancomycin:

  • In Enterococcus infective endocarditis patients with penicillin allergy or penicillin resistant strains, the drug of choice in the treatment of such cases is vancomycin.
  • Enterococci are intrinsically resistant to a wide array of antimicrobial agents, and they are generally resistant to killing by any of the single agents (e.g., ampicillin or vancomycin) that are bactericidal for most other gram-positive cocci.
  • Effective bactericidal activity can only be achieved with the combination of a cell wall–active agent, such as ampicillin or vancomycin, and an aminoglycoside, such as gentamicin or streptomycin.

questions.text: In which of the following bacteria is increased penicillin drug resistance is noted?

Correct Option B - Neisseria gonorrhoeae:

  • Meningococci were uniformly sensitive to penicillin and other antibiotics, but resistant strains have emerged and become common in many areas.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most specific disease of Streptococcus agalactiae?

questions.text: A patient came to the OPD with an injury caused by a rusted metal. What is the mechanism of action of Tetanus?

choices.text: Inhibit the release of GABA and Glycine

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Inhibit the release of GABA and Glycine:

  • Tetanospasmin is the toxin responsible for tetanus
  • Tetanospasmin resembles strychnine in its effects. The tetanus toxin specifically blocks synaptic inhibition in the spinal cord, presumably at inhibitory terminals that use glycine and GABA as neurotransmitters.
  • The abolition of spinal inhibition causes uncontrolled spread of impulses initiated anywhere in the central nervous system.
  • This results in muscle rigidity and spasms due to the simultane - ous contraction of agonists and antagonists, in the absence of reciprocal inhibition.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Inhibition of protein synthesis: Shiga toxin or verotoxin which is similar to EHEC verotoxin acts by inhibition of protein synthesis.

Option B - Inhibit the release of Ach: Botulinum toxin acts by inhibiting the release of ACh.

Option D - Inhibit the release of Norepinephrine: Release of norepinephrine is inhibited by certain drugs like alpha-2 agonists.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is spread via all components of blood?

  • Campylobacter jejuni, commonly involved in food poisoning, is a causative agent of small bowel maltoma.
  • Borrelia burgdorferi, causes lyme disease which is involved in causing skin Mlatoma.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of fever, abdominal pain and diarrhoea for 3 days. He further gives the history of consumption of raw fish 3 days back. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities. Further investigation reveals that there is no pus in the stool. Culture grew in Wagatsuma agar. Which causative agent is the most likely to have caused this illness?
questions.solution:
Correct option D - Vibrio parahaemolyticus:

  • This is a case of acute gastroenteritis as the patient presents with complaints of fever, diarrhoea and abdominal pain for 3 days.
  • Further history reveals that he had consumed raw fish 3 days back.
  • The most likely agent to have caused this illness is Vibrio parahaemolyticus.
  • Vibrio parahaemolyticus causes gastroenteritis. It is also found in raw fish. The selective media is Wagatsuma agar.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Vibrio cholerae:

  • Vibrio cholerae causes cholera.

Option B - Salmonella typhi:

  • Salmonella typhi is the causative agent of enteric fever.

questions.text: A 54-year-old female with a history of rheumatic heart disease underwent prosthetic valve replacement surgery 6 months ago. He presents to the cardiology clinic with complaints of fever, fatigue, and worsening shortness of breath over the past few weeks. Physical examination reveals a new heart murmur and splinter hemorrhages on the nail beds. Based on the clinical presentation, what is the most likely causative organism responsible for this patient's infective endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Staphylococcus epidermidis

  • Staphylococcus epidermidis a coagulase-negative staphylococci is a common cause of prosthetic valve endocarditis, especially within the first year after surgery

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Streptococcus viridans: This is a common cause of native valve endocarditis, not prosthetic valve endocarditis. Streptococcus viridans is a part of the normal flora of the mouth and throat and can cause endocarditis after dental procedures or in people with poor oral hygiene.

Option C - Enterococcus faecalis: This bacterium is a common cause of healthcare-associated infections, including urinary tract infections, wound infections, and, less commonly, endocarditis. While it can cause endocarditis, it is not the most likely cause in this patient who has a prosthetic heart valve.

Option D - Staphylococcus saprophyticus: Staphylococcus saprophyticus is a coagulase-negative staphylococci associated with urinary tract infections commonly.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents to the pediatric clinic with complaints of joint pain, swelling, and difficulty in walking. On examination, the child is found to have a tender, swollen knee joint and a history of recent sore throat. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated antistreptolysin O (ASO) titers. A renal biopsy is performed, and it shows glomerular changes consistent with PSGN. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for both the acute rheumatic fever and PSGN in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Streptococcus pyogenes 

  • Streptococcus pyogenes, also known as group A Streptococcus, is the correct answer. This bacterium is responsible for both acute rheumatic fever (ARF) and post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). ARF is a systemic immune-mediated inflammatory disorder that can develop after an untreated or inadequately treated streptococcal pharyngitis (sore throat). It can lead to joint pain, inflammation, and other clinical manifestations. PSGN, on the other hand, is a kidney disease that can occur as a result of an immune response to a streptococcal infection, particularly in the skin or throat. The elevated antistreptolysin O (ASO) titers and the glomerular changes seen on renal biopsy in the given scenario are indicative of a streptococcal infection-related condition.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Streptococcus pneumoniae: Streptococcus pneumoniae is a common cause of bacterial pneumonia and other respiratory infections. It is not typically associated with acute rheumatic fever or post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN).

Option C - Streptococcus agalactiae: Streptococcus agalactiae, also known as group B Streptococcus, is a common cause of neonatal infections and can also cause infections in adults with underlying medical conditions. It is not associated with acute rheumatic fever or PSGN.

Option D - Streptococcus mutans: Streptococcus mutans is primarily associated with dental caries and oral infections. It is not a common cause of acute rheumatic fever or PSGN.

questions.text: A neonate admitted with the features of meningitis. Bacteria isolated from CSF is bacitracin resistant. Neonatal meningitis is caused by which organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B Streptococcus)

  • This is the correct answer. Group B Streptococcus is a known cause of neonatal meningitis, particularly in the first few days after birth. It is often found in the birth canal of asymptomatic carriers and can be transmitted to the newborn during delivery. Bacitracin resistance is a characteristic feature of Group B Streptococcus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pneumococcus (Streptococcus pneumoniae): Pneumococcus is a common cause of bacterial meningitis, but it is not typically associated with neonatal meningitis. Pneumococcus is generally sensitive to bacitracin.

Option B - Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus): Streptococcus pyogenes is more commonly associated with conditions like strep throat and skin infections. It is not a common cause of neonatal meningitis, and it is also sensitive to bacitracin.

Option D - Meningococci (Neisseria meningitidis): Meningococcal meningitis is more common in older children and adults. It is not a common cause of neonatal meningitis. Neisseria meningitidis is typically sensitive to bacitracin.

questions.text: A 28 year old patient presented with watery diarrhoea and dysentery. After taking history, it is noted that he had eaten Oysters on his recent trip. Which of the following can be responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Vibrio Parahemolyticus

  • Vibrio parahemolyticus is a bacterium commonly associated with consuming raw or undercooked seafood, particularly oysters. It causes gastroenteritis with symptoms like watery diarrhea, abdominal cramps, nausea, vomiting, and sometimes low-grade fever. The incubation period is usually short, ranging from a few hours to a couple of days after consuming contaminated seafood.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Staph aureus: Staphylococcus aureus is a bacterium that can cause food poisoning when certain strains produce toxins. However, symptoms usually manifest within a few hours of consuming contaminated food and involve rapid onset of nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, and occasionally diarrhea. This bacterium is not typically associated with dysentery (bloody diarrhea) as described in the patient's case.

Option C - E. coli: Certain strains of Escherichia coli (E. coli) can cause foodborne illnesses, including those leading to diarrhea. However, these infections are not usually associated with dysentery. E. coli strains like enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) or enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) tend to cause watery diarrhea rather than dysentery.

Option D - Vibrio Cholerae: Vibrio cholerae is responsible for causing cholera, which leads to profuse watery diarrhea, rapid dehydration, and electrolyte imbalances. Cholera typically results in a "rice-water" appearance of stools due to its watery nature. While cholera can lead to severe diarrhea, it does not usually cause dysentery with bloody stools.

questions.text: Among the following conditions, which one does not result from exotoxins?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Meningitis:

  • Meningitis is typically the result of a direct invasion of the meninges by bacteria or viruses, and it is not primarily caused by the production of exotoxins.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - HUS: HUS is often associated with Shiga toxin-producing E. coli (STEC) infections. Shiga toxin is an example of an exotoxin, and it plays a role in the pathogenesis of HUS.

Option C - Toxic shock syndrome: TSS is typically caused by exotoxins produced by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes. Exotoxins are a primary factor in the development of TSS.

Option D - Pseudomembranous colitis: Pseudomembranous colitis is primarily caused by Clostridium difficile infection. The main virulence factor in C. difficile infection is the production of toxins (exotoxins), particularly toxins A and B, which contribute to the characteristic symptoms of this condition.

questions.text: A patient has presented with fever and blister on the hand, followed by the development of axillary lymphadenopathy. What will you ask the patient with regard to history?

choices.text: History of similar complaints among family members

  • It occurs when an infected cat licks a person’s open wound or bites or scratches a person hard enough to break the surface of the skin.  It is caused by the bacteria Bartonella henselae, characterized by a febrile illness with lymphadenopathy.

Option D - History of louse bite: A louse bite can cause epidemic typhus characterized by fever and a rash starting from the trunk and spreading to the limbs sparing palms and sole without regional lymphadenopathy.
