questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal pain, diarrhea, and a step-ladder pattern fever. He also complains of a headache and malaise. His symptoms gradually worsened over the past 2 weeks. Which of the following is the best diagnostic test?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Widal Test:

  • The patient presents with symptoms of enteric fever, a systemic illness caused by Salmonella typhi or Salmonella paratyphi. A step-ladder pattern fever is a characteristic feature.
  • The best diagnostic method for enteric fever in the second week of symptom onset is the Widal test, which detects antibodies against S. typhi and S. paratyphi in the patient's serum. 
  • It is a serological test that detects antibodies against O (surface) and H (flagellar) antigens.
  • An antibody titer of greater than 1:60 for O antigen and greater than 1:180 for H antigen, is considered a cutoff level to predict recent infection of typhoid fever in an endemic area.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Stool Culture: This is helpful in diagnosing enteric fever in the 3rd week of infection.

Option C - Blood Culture: Blood culture remains the primary mechanism of confirmation of typhoid fever in the 1st week of the infection.

Option D - Urine Culture: Urine culture is helpful in diagnosing enteric fever in the 4th week of the infection.

questions.text: Mw vaccine is extracted from which bacteria, mentioned below :
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - M. indicus Pranii:

  • M. indicus pranii: Mw vaccine, also known as the Mw immunotherapeutic vaccine, is extracted from Mycobacterium indicus pranii. It is a heat-killed whole-cell preparation of this non-pathogenic mycobacterium.

Incorrect Option:

Option B - M. Ulcerans: M. ulcerans causes Buruli ulcer, which produces exotoxin myolactone.

Option C - M. Leprae: M. leprae is the causative agent of leprosy, not used for the production of the Mw vaccine.

Option D - M. Bovis: M. bovis is a pathogenic bacterium that causes bovine tuberculosis. It is not involved in the production of the Mw vaccine.

questions.text: The toxin produced by the organism shown below acts via ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - ADP ribosylation of EF2:

  • The gram staining shows gram-positive bacilli with a characteristic appearance resembling a Chinese letter (V or L shaped) or cuneiform arrangement, and the ends show metachromatic granules, giving it a club-shaped appearance suggestive of Corynebacterium diphtheriae.
  • The toxin produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae, known as diphtheria toxin, acts by ADP ribosylation of EF2.
  • It is a bipartite. Fragment B helps in binding, and fragment A inhibits polypeptide chain elongation in the presence of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide, inactivating the elongation factor EF-2.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Increase in cAMP: This mechanism is associated with toxins such as cholera toxin and pertussis toxin, not the toxin produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Option B - Increase in cGMP: This mechanism is associated with toxins such as heat-stable enterotoxins of E. coli.

Option D - 60s ribosome: This mechanism is associated with toxins such as Shiga toxin and verocytotoxin.

questions.text: A 48 years old man, hospitalized for 17 days and on IV antibiotics followed by oral course of drugs for acute febrile illness with neutropenia. He had a history of dysuria while admitted and now complaints of loose stools and abdominal pain. Which antibiotic usage has the highest risk for developing pseudomembranous colitis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Aminopenicillin:

  • Pseudomembranous colitis, also known as Clostridium difficile-associated colitis, is a severe inflammatory condition of the colon that can occur as a result of antibiotic usage. Certain antibiotics are known to disrupt the normal gut flora and create an environment favourable for the overgrowth of Clostridium difficile bacteria, leading to the development of pseudomembranous colitis.
  • Among the options provided, aminopenicillin antibiotics have the highest risk for causing pseudomembranous colitis. Aminopenicillins, such as ampicillin and amoxicillin, are broad-spectrum antibiotics commonly used to treat various bacterial infections. However, they can also disrupt the balance of the gut microbiota and increase the risk of Clostridium difficile infection.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Carbapenems: Carbapenems are a class of broad-spectrum antibiotics with a lower risk of causing pseudomembranous colitis compared to aminopenicillins. Although they can still disrupt the gut microbiota, their use is not typically associated with a significantly high risk of Clostridium difficile infection.

Option C - Macrolides: Macrolide antibiotics, such as erythromycin and azithromycin, are known to have a lower risk of causing pseudomembranous colitis compared to aminopenicillins. While they can still alter the gut microbiota, they are not considered as high-risk antibiotics for Clostridium difficile infection.

Option D - Fluoroquinolones: Fluoroquinolone antibiotics, including ciprofloxacin and levofloxacin, have a moderate risk of causing pseudomembranous colitis. While their use can disrupt the gut microbiota and increase the risk of Clostridium difficile infection, the risk is lower compared to aminopenicillins.

questions.text: What is the most probable cause in a case of granuloma with acid-fast bacilli positivity?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Leprosy:

  • When encountering a case of granuloma with positive acid-fast bacilli (AFB), leprosy is the most likely cause. Leprosy, also known as Hansen's disease, is a chronic infectious disease caused by the bacteria Mycobacterium leprae. It primarily affects the skin, peripheral nerves, mucosa of the upper respiratory tract, and the eyes.
  • Leprosy is characterized by the formation of granulomas in the affected tissues, which are clusters of immune cells, including macrophages, that surround and attempt to contain the mycobacteria. Acid-fast staining is a diagnostic test used to visualize mycobacteria, such as Mycobacterium leprae, which retain the stain despite being exposed to acid.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Cat scratch disease: Cat scratch disease is caused by the bacterium Bartonella henselae, and it typically presents with swollen lymph nodes and a papule or pustule at the site of a cat scratch or bite. It does not cause granulomas with positive AFB staining.

Option B - Trench fever: Trench fever is caused by the bacterium Bartonella quintana and is transmitted by body lice. It is characterized by recurrent fever, headache, and bone pain. Trench fever does not typically present with granulomas or positive AFB staining.

Option D - Syphilis: Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. It presents with painless genital ulcer and inguinal lymph node, condylomata lata, and neurosyphilis. However, syphilis does not commonly present with granulomas or positive AFB staining.

questions.text: Legionnaires disease is implicated in causation of which among the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Respiratory Disease:

  • Legionnaires disease is a severe form of pneumonia caused by the bacterium Legionella pneumophila. It primarily affects the respiratory system, leading to respiratory disease symptoms like mild fever, myalgia, non-productive cough, and respiratory failure.
  • The bacteria Legionella pneumophila are transmitted through inhalation of contaminated water droplets, typically from sources such as air conditioning systems, hot tubs, or showers. 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. These conditions are not associated with legionnaire's disease.

questions.text: Hemolytic uremic syndrome is associated with?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - E. Coli 0157:

  • Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) is a condition characterized by the combination of hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury. HUS can have several causes, but the most common and well-known association is with infection by the bacterium Escherichia coli (E. coli) serotype O157:H7 and shigella.
  • E. coli O157: H7 is a strain of E. coli that produces toxins called Shiga toxins. These toxins can cause damage to the lining of blood vessels, leading to red blood cell destruction, platelet clumping, and kidney injury, which are characteristic features of HUS.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Malaria: Malaria is caused by Plasmodium parasites transmitted by infected mosquitoes. It is characterized by fever, and severe cases of cerebral malaria caused by P. falciparum can be seen. It is not typically associated with HUS.

Option C - Parvovirus B19: Parvovirus B19 is a viral infection that primarily affects children and can cause a condition called erythema infectiosum (fifth disease).

Option D - Bartonella Henselae: It is a bacterium that causes cat scratch disease, a usually benign infection characterized by swollen lymph nodes and fever. Bartonella infections can have various manifestations, including neurologic and cardiac complications, they are not typically associated with HUS.

questions.text: Which bacteria show Quellung reaction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Streptococcus Pneumoniae:

  • The Quellung reaction is a phenomenon in which the capsule surrounding bacteria swells and becomes more visible when exposed to specific antibodies. Streptococcus pneumoniae is known to exhibit the Quellung reaction.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: In the small intestine, cholera toxin acts by:

choices.text: ADP ribosylation of the G protein

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - ADP ribosylation of the G protein:

  • Cholera toxin produced by Vibrio cholerae acts by ADP ribosylation of the G protein in the intestinal cells by the A1 subunit of the toxin, leading to increased production of cyclic AMP (cAMP) and subsequent activation of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) ion channel, resulting in massive secretion of electrolytes and water into the lumen of the small intestine.

Incorrect Options :

Option B - Inhibition of adenyl cyclase: Cholera toxin actually stimulates adenyl cyclase, leading to increased production of cAMP.

Option C - Activation of GTPase: Cholera toxin does not activate GTPase. It acts by ADP ribosylation of the G protein.

Option D - Active absorption of NaCl: Cholera toxin disrupts the normal absorption of electrolytes and water, resulting in excessive fluid secretion rather than active absorption of NaCl.

questions.text: BCYE medium is used to culture:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Legionella:

  • BCYE (Buffered Charcoal Yeast Extract) medium is a specialized culture medium that supports the growth of Legionella bacteria. Legionella is a pathogenic bacterium responsible for causing a severe respiratory illness known as Legionnaires' disease.
  • BCYE medium contains yeast extract, which provides essential growth factors, and activated charcoal, which helps to absorb and neutralize inhibitory substances, buffered salts maintain the appropriate pH. Legionellae grow slowly; visible colonies are usually present after 3 days of incubation. Colonies are round or flat with entire edges. They vary in color from colorless to iridescent pink or blue and are translucent or speckled.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Leptospira: Leptospira is a spirochete bacterium that causes an infectious disease known as leptospirosis. It is typically cultured using specific media such as the Ellinghausen-McCullough-Johnson-Harris (EMJH) medium.

Option B - Bacillus cereus: Bacillus cereus is a gram-positive bacterium that can cause food poisoning. It is cultured on mannitol egg yolk phenol red polymyxin (MYPA) agar.

Option C - Campylobacter: Campylobacter is a genus of bacteria that includes species responsible for gastrointestinal infections, such as Campylobacter jejuni. Campylobacter is commonly cultured using selective media like Skirrow's, Butzlers, or Campy BAP selective medium.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is admitted with fever, icterus, conjunctival injection, and hematuria for 15 days. Which serological test should be done for diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Microscopic Agglutination Test:

  • The patient's presentation of fever, jaundice, conjunctival injection, and hematuria are classic symptoms of leptospirosis, aka hepatorenal syndrome, aka Weil's disease, caused by leptospira interrogans.
  • Microscopic Agglutination Test (MAT) is the specific and most commonly used serological test for diagnosing Leptospirosis. It detects the presence of antibodies against Leptospira bacteria in the patient's serum. The test involves agglutination reactions between the patient's serum and a panel of different Leptospira serovars. A positive result indicates the presence of specific antibodies and confirms the diagnosis of Leptospirosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Widal test: It is primarily used for diagnosing typhoid fever caused by Salmonella typhi and Salmonella paratyphi.

Option C - Weil-Felix reaction: The Weil-Felix reaction is a serological test that uses cross-reacting antigens from different Proteus strains to detect antibodies against rickettsial infections.

Option D - Paul-Bunnell test: The Paul-Bunnell test, also known as the Monospot test, is used for the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis, which is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).

questions.text: A veterinarian developed an ulcer with a central black eschar over the forearm, as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Bacillus Anthracis:

  • The image shows an ulcer with a central black eschar on the forearm, and the occupation of the patient is highly suggestive of cutaneous anthrax, which is caused by the bacterium Bacillus anthracis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pseudomonas Aeruginosa: Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a common cause of various hospital-acquired infections like meningitis, endocarditis, and infection of burns.

Option B - Yersinia Pestis: Yersinia pestis is the causative organism of plague, which typically presents with symptoms such as fever, lymphadenopathy, respiratory symptoms, and shock.

Option D - Francisella Tularensis: Francisella tularensis is the bacterium responsible for tularemia, also known as rabbit fever. It primarily causes ulceroglandular tularemia, which presents with skin ulcers and swollen lymph nodes.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used as an immediate test in the screening of urinary tract infections (UTI)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pour Plate Culture:

  • Pour plate culture is not used as an immediate test in the screening of urinary tract infections (UTIs). Pour plate culture is a quantitative method used for bacterial culture and enumeration, it is not a screening test for UTI.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Griess Nitrite Test: The Griess Nitrite test is a rapid screening test used to detect the presence of nitrites in the urine. Nitrites are produced by certain bacteria, such as Escherichia coli, commonly associated with UTIs. The presence of nitrites indicates the possibility of a UTI.

Option C - Leukocyte Esterase Test: The leukocyte esterase test is a rapid screening test used to detect the leukocyte esterase secreted by pus cells in the urine. The presence of leukocyte esterase suggests inflammation and a possible UTI.

Option D - Wet Mount Examination: The wet mount examination is a microscopic examination of urine sediment, which is used for the detection of pus cells in urine. Pyuria of more than 8 pus cells/mm3 is taken as significant for UTI.

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for neurosyphilis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Venereal Disease Research Laboratory (VDRL) Test:

  • Neurosyphilis is a form of syphilis that affects the central nervous system. The VDRL test is the most preferred screening test for syphilis, including neurosyphilis.
  • The VDRL test is a non-specific test that detects reagin antibodies in the serum or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) of individuals with syphilis by using cardiolipin antigen extracted from beef heart. Positive VDRL results indicate the presence of antibodies, suggesting an active infection.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - FTA-ABS-Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption Test: The FTA-ABS test is a specific test for syphilis. It detects antibodies specifically against Treponema pallidum, the bacterium that causes syphilis. It is highly sensitive and specific for syphilis diagnosis, including neurosyphilis. However, the FTA-ABS test is not the investigation of choice specifically for neurosyphilis.

Option C - RPR – Rapid Plasma Reagin Test: The RPR test is another non-specific test used for the screening and diagnosis of syphilis. It detects antibodies against cardiolipin, a substance found in the plasma. It is more expensive than VDRL.

Option D - TPI – Treponema Pallidum Immobilization Test: The TPI test is a specific test used to detect antibodies against Treponema pallidum. It involves mixing patient serum with live Treponema pallidum organisms and observing for immobilization.

questions.text: Contact based isolation is employed for which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - MRSA:

  • Contact-based isolation precautions are employed for MRSA (Methicillin Resistance Staphylococcus Aureus). These precautions prevent the transmission of the bacteria from an infected or colonized individual to others.
  • It includes hand washing, isolation of patients with open staphylococcal lesions, and detection of staphylococcal lesions among surgeons.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Diphtheria: It requires droplet precautions because it is primarily transmitted through respiratory droplets. Droplet precautions involve wearing a mask and other appropriate measures to prevent the spread of infectious droplets.

Option C - Mumps: It is also transmitted through respiratory droplets, and droplet precautions are necessary to prevent its transmission.

Option D -Asthma: It is a chronic respiratory condition and not an infectious disease. It does not require isolation precautions since it is not transmissible from person to person.

questions.text: An 18 year old female presents with a severe headache and high fever of 101°F. On examination, papilloedema and nuchal rigidity was present. Gram staining of the CSF is shown below. Causative organism is
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Neisseria Meningitidis:

  • The clinical presentation of the patient is suggestive of meningitis.
  • The most common bacterium responsible for meningitis are Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, H. influenzae, Listeria, streptococcus agalactiae, and E. coli.
  • Gram staining of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) showing gram-negative diplococci suggests the diagnosis of Neisseria meningitidis.

Incorrect Options :

Option A - Haemophilus Influenzae Type B: While Haemophilus influenzae can cause meningitis, it is a gram-negative present as clusters of coccobacillus and would not appear as gram-positive diplococci on Gram staining.

Option C - Streptococcus Pneumoniae: Streptococcus pneumoniae is a gram-positive bacterium that can cause bacterial meningitis, but it appears as gram-positive diplococci, giving a lanceolate shape.
Option D - Listeria Monocytogenes: Listeria monocytogenes is a gram-positive bacterium associated with meningitis, but it is characterized by its rod-shaped and exhibits differential motility.

questions.text: What does Burkholderia cepacia exhibit resistance to among the options provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Cefotetan:

  • Burkholderia cepacia is known to exhibit intrinsic resistance to cefotetan.
  • This resistance is primarily attributed to the presence of various mechanisms, including efflux pumps, enzymatic degradation, and alterations in target sites.
  • Burkholderia cepacia is resistant to aminoglycosides, polymyxine, 1st and 2nd generation cephalosporins, and carboxypenicillins.
  • Burkholderia cepacia is susceptible to Ceftazidime, Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, Temocillin, doxycycline, meropenem, and piperacillin.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to Option D for an explanation.

questions.text: What is the causative agent for scombroid food poisoning among the following organisms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Pseudomonas Aeruginosa:

  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative bacterium that can cause various infections in humans.
  • Scombroid poisoning is caused by the consumption of fish.
  • Organisms responsible for causing Scombroid poisoning are Morganella morganii, Escherichia coli, Klebsiella species, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
  • They are commensal in seafish and can break down histidine present in fish into histamine, which can cause food poisoning following seafood intake.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Salmonella: Salmonella is a group of bacteria that causes typhoid fever characterized by step ladder pattern fever, bradycardia, and pea soup diarrhea.

Option B- Staphylococcus: It causes food poisoning with the consumption of milk and meat products with an incubation period of 1 to 6 hours.

Option D- Peptostreptococcus: Peptostreptococcus is a genus of anaerobic bacteria that can be part of skin, mouth, intestine, and vagina. It is associated with puerperal sepsis and skin and soft tissue infection.

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Bacteriophage:

  • Bacterial transduction occurs through the action of bacteriophages, which transfer bacterial genetic material from one bacterium to another.

Types of Bacteriophages

While plasmids can carry genetic information and can be transferred between bacteria through a process called conjugation where plasmids are transferred between bacteria through direct physical contact.

Option B - Sex pilli: Sex pilli, or pili, are appendages found on the surface of certain bacteria that facilitate the transfer of genetic material during conjugation.

questions.text: TB test done only on whole blood sample is ______________.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Interferon-gamma release assay:

  • Interferon-gamma release assay (IGRA) is a type of tuberculosis (TB) test that is performed on whole blood samples.
  • IGRA tests measure the release of interferon-gamma by T-cells in response to specific TB antigens (ESAT, 6TB 7.7, and CFP 10).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - TrueNat TB: TrueNat TB is a molecular diagnostic test for the detection of tuberculosis. It utilizes a cartridge-based platform to perform real-time PCR (polymerase chain reaction) to detect Mycobacterium tuberculosis DNA in sputum samples. TrueNet TB is not specifically limited to whole blood samples, as it is primarily used for sputum-based testing.

Option B - GeneXpert: GeneXpert is a molecular diagnostic platform that uses real-time PCR technology to detect tuberculosis and resistance against rifampicin. The test is typically performed on sputum samples or other respiratory specimens rather than whole blood.

Option D - MGIT system: It is a molecular diagnostic platform that uses probe-based detection of amplified DNA in the specimen to detect tuberculosis and resistance 1st line and 2nd line antitubercular drugs. The test is typically performed on sputum samples or other respiratory specimens.

questions.text: What causes the formation of multiple abscesses with discharging sinuses that show the presence of sulphur granules in the pus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Actinomyces Israelii:

  • Multiple abscesses with discharging sinuses and the presence of sulfur granules in pus are characteristic features of actinomycosis caused by actinomyces israelii a commensal bacterium in the oral flora.
  • Actinomyces form aggregates called sulfur granules, which are composed of bacterial colonies surrounded by host tissue reaction. These granules are typically yellowish and contain tangled filamentous structures seen on microscopy.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Nocardia: Nocardia can cause pulmonary infections in immunocompromised individuals and cutaneous lesions in immunocompetent individuals.

Option C - Salmonella: Salmonella bacteria are primarily associated with gastrointestinal infections, such as dysentery characterized by bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever.

Option D - Tularemia: Tularemia, also known as rabbit fever, is caused by the bacterium Francisella tularensis. It typically presents as a flu-like illness with symptoms such as fever, fatigue, and swollen lymph nodes.

questions.text: Which antibiotics are Mycoplasma naturally resistant to?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Beta-lactam Antibiotics:

  • Beta-lactam antibiotics: Mycoplasma is inherently resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics.
  • This is because mycoplasmas lack a cell wall, which is the target of penicillins (like β-lactamase inhibitors) and cephalosporins.
  • The absence of a cell wall makes mycoplasmas naturally resistant to these types of antibiotics.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Macrolides: Mycoplasma is susceptible to macrolide antibiotics such as erythromycin, azithromycin, and clarithromycin. Macrolides are commonly used in the treatment of mycoplasma infections.

Option C - Tetracycline: Mycoplasma is susceptible to tetracycline antibiotics. Tetracyclines, including doxycycline and minocycline, are often effective in treating mycoplasma infections.

Option D - Fluoroquinolones: Mycoplasma is susceptible to fluoroquinolone antibiotics such as ciprofloxacin and levofloxacin. Fluoroquinolones are commonly used in the treatment of mycoplasma infections.

  • Bacillus anthracis, the bacterium responsible for anthrax, is a Gram-positive bacterium that appears as rods under a microscope. These rods have square or boxy ends arranged in a chain, giving a bamboo stick or box car appearance.

questions.text: HUS in children is caused by:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - E. coli 0157:

  • Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) is a condition characterized by the combination of hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury. HUS can have several causes, but the most common and well-known association is with infection by the bacterium Escherichia coli (E. coli) serotype O157:H7 and shigella.
  • E. coli O157:H7 is a strain of E. coli that produces toxins called Shiga toxins. These toxins can cause damage to the lining of blood vessels, leading to red blood cell destruction, platelet clumping, and kidney injury, which are characteristic features of HUS.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Malaria: Malaria is caused by Plasmodium parasites transmitted by infected mosquitoes. It is characterized by fever, and severe cases of cerebral malaria caused by P. falciparum can be seen. It is not typically associated with HUS.

Option C - Parvovirus B19: Parvovirus B19 is a viral infection that primarily affects children and can cause a condition called erythema infectiosum (fifth disease).

Option D - Bartonella henselae: It is a bacterium that causes cat scratch disease, a usually benign infection characterized by swollen lymph nodes and fever. Bartonella infections can have various manifestations, including neurologic and cardiac complications, they are not typically associated with HUS.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female comes to the outpatient department complaining of fever, cough, muscle pain and headache. On taking occupational history, she reveals working for a centrally airconditioned corporate company. The doctor sent a sputum sample for culture sensitivity. The microbiologist used buffered charcoal yeast extract to culture the suspected organism. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Legionnaire Disease:

  • The symptoms and occupational history described are consistent with Legionnaire's disease, caused by the bacterium Legionella pneumophila. The use of buffered charcoal yeast extract medium is specific for culturing Legionella species.
  • Legionella inhabits aquatic bodies, which could be either:
    • Natural water sources, such as rivers, streams, or even inside amoeba
    • Artificial aquatic sources, such as air conditioners, water coolers, shower heads, large plumbing systems, and decorative fountains.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Brucellosis: Brucellosis is caused by Brucella species and is typically associated with exposure to infected animals or their products.

Option C - Pneumonia caused by Haemophilus: Haemophilus influenzae is a common causative organism of meningitis, pneumonia, croup, and suppurative lesions and requires Factor X and V for growth.

Option D - Acute gastroenteritis: Acute gastroenteritis is characterized by fever, nausea, vomiting or diarrhea.

questions.text: When should you perform Widal test in a case of typhoid?
questions.solution:

  • Performing the Widal test in the 2nd week of illness is considered the most appropriate timing for obtaining reliable and accurate results. During the 2nd week of typhoid fever, the patient's immune response has had sufficient time to produce detectable levels of antibodies against Salmonella typhi antigens.
  • Tests performed for the diagnosis of typhoid during the course of infection.

questions.text: Which toxin acts via the mechanism depicted in the image below ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Botulinum:

  • Botulinum toxin is produced by the bacterium Clostridium botulinum and has a specific mechanism of action
  • Mechanism of action:
    • Binding: Botulinum toxin binds to presynaptic nerve terminals at the neuromuscular junction.
    • Internalization: The toxin is internalized into the nerve terminal via receptor-mediated endocytosis.
    • Cleavage: Inside the nerve terminal, the toxin undergoes enzymatic cleavage, resulting in the formation of two subunits: a light chain (LC) and a heavy chain (HC).
    • Neurotransmitter release inhibition: The light chain (LC) of the botulinum toxin is a protease that specifically cleaves SNARE proteins involved in neurotransmitter release. SNARE proteins play a crucial role in the fusion of synaptic vesicles containing acetylcholine with the neuronal membrane, allowing the release of acetylcholine into the synaptic cleft. By cleaving SNARE proteins, botulinum toxin prevents the release of acetylcholine, leading to muscle paralysis.
    • Temporary effects: The effects of botulinum toxin are reversible, as new SNARE proteins can be synthesized by the affected neuron over time. The duration of paralysis depends on the type of botulinum toxin used and the individual's metabolism.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: A patient from Uttarakhand presented in the month of September with fever and myalgia after a bite with a mite. The patient was started on IV ceftriaxone, but it did not help; later, the patient noticed cutaneous lesions on examination (black eschar), as given below in the figure. What is your diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Scrub Typhus:

  • The patient presenting with fever, myalgia, and cutaneous lesions (black eschar) after a bite with a mite in Uttarakhand during September is suggestive of Scrub typhus.
  • Scrub typhus is a bacterial infection caused by the Orientia tsutsugamushi bacterium. It is transmitted to humans through the bite of infected chiggers (larva of trombiculid mites) found in areas with dense vegetation. Scrub typhus is commonly seen in rural areas, particularly in regions with heavy vegetation, such as forests or grasslands.
  • The clinical presentation of scrub typhus includes fever, headache, myalgia (muscle pain), and a characteristic eschar at the site of the chigger bite. The eschar is a black, necrotic lesion surrounded by an area of inflammation.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Murine Typhus: Murine typhus is caused by the bacteria Rickettsia typhi, transmitted to humans by rubbing or inhalation of the feces of infected fleas. It typically presents with fever, headache, myalgia, anorexia, and rash (involving the trunk more often than the extremities).

Option C - Q Fever: Q fever is caused by the bacteria Coxiella burnetii, transmitted to humans through ingestion of contaminated milk or by handling wools, hides or meat. It can cause a flu-like illness, hepatitis, meningoencephalitis or endocarditis.

Option D - Louse Borne Typhus: Louse-borne typhus also known as epidemic typhus, is caused by the bacteria Rickettsia prowazekii and is transmitted to humans through rubbing of louse (Pediculus humanus corporis) feces on an abraded skin. It presents with high fever, headache, and rash starting from trunk and spreading to limbs.

questions.text: The test shown below, which uses a bacitracin disc, is useful in identifying …………

Correct Option B - Streptococcus Pyogenes:

  • The test being referred to is the bacitracin susceptibility test. In this test, a disc containing a standardized concentration of bacitracin is placed on a blood agar culture plate that has been inoculated with the bacterial isolate. Streptococcus pyogenes is highly sensitive to bacitracin than other streptococci, showing wide range of inhibition as shown in the image.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus is resistant to bacitracin, so it would not show a zone of inhibition around the disc in this test.

Option C - Staphylococcus epidermidis: Staphylococcus epidermidis is resistant to bacitracin, so it would not show a zone of inhibition around the disc in this test.

Option D - Streptococcus agalactiae: Streptococcus agalactiae is resistant to bacitracin, so it would not show a zone of inhibition around the disc in this test.

questions.text: A cook prepares sandwiches for 10 people going for picnic. Eight out of them develop severe gastroenteritis within 4-6 hrs of consumption of the sandwiches. It is likely that on investigations the cook is found to be the carrier of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Staphylococcus Aureus:

  • Staphylococcus aureus is a bacterium that can cause food poisoning when contaminated food, particularly carbohydrate and protein-rich food, milk, meat, and fish, is consumed.
  • Staphylococcus aureus can produce heat-stable enterotoxins that can withstand 100°C for 10 to 40 minutes and cause rapid-onset symptoms of nausea and vomiting, typically occurring within a few hours (within 6 hours is characteristic) of ingesting contaminated food.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Salmonella typhi: Salmonella typhi is the bacterium responsible for causing typhoid fever. It is transmitted through the ingestion of contaminated food or water. However, the incubation period for typhoid fever is usually much longer, ranging from 7 to 14 days.

Option B - Vibrio cholerae: Vibrio cholerae is the bacterium that causes cholera, a severe diarrheal disease. Cholera is typically associated with the ingestion of contaminated water or food, usually in settings with poor sanitation. The incubation period for cholera is less than 24 hours to 5 days.

Option C - Entamoeba histolytica: Entamoeba histolytica is a protozoan parasite that causes amoebic dysentery, a form of severe diarrhea. The incubation period for amoebic dysentery is typically longer, ranging from 2 weeks to 4 weeks.

Correct Option C - Toluidine and Malachite Green:

  • The constituents of Albert's stain are as follows:
    • Albert solution 1:

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used for typhoid fever in adults ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Amikacin:

  • Amikacin is not commonly used for the treatment of typhoid fever in adults. Typhoid fever is a systemic bacterial infection caused by Salmonella typhi, and appropriate antibiotic therapy is essential for effective treatment.
  • The currently recommended drugs are as follows:
    • Third-generation cephalosporins: Ceftriaxone is the drug of choice for empirical treatment; given 1–2 g/day, IV, for 10–14 Days
    • Azithromycin: Alternative drug for empirical therapy. Given orally, 1g/day for 5 days.
    • Fluoroquinolones, e.g., ciprofloxacin: It can be given only if it is found susceptible. It is given as 500 mg twice a day orally for 5 days.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to Option D of an explanation.

questions.text: What is the incubation period of lymphogranuloma venereum ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 3-35 days:

  • The incubation period of lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is typically between 3 days to 5 weeks.
  • Lymphogranuloma venereum is a sexually transmitted infection caused by L1, L2, and L3 serovars of the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis, after which a small, painless, papulovesicular lesion appears on the genitalia.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation.

questions.text: Identify the organism shown below, which causes effacement and attachment of intestinal cells.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - EPEC:

  • Attachment - effacement lesion in intestinal mucosa is caused by EPEC (Enteropathogenic Escherichia coli).
  • Enteropathogenic E coli are non-invasive and do not produce enterotoxins.
  • EPEC has two factors:
    • EPEC adherence factor (EAF)
    • The chromosomal locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE) pathogenicity island that promotes the tight adherence characteristic of EPEC (attachment and effacement).
  • After attachment, there is a loss of microvilli (effacement) and formation of filamentous actin pedestals or cuplike structures, causing entry of the EPEC into the mucosal cells. This attachment-effacement lesion disrupts the normal absorptive function of the intestinal epithelium and can lead to diarrhea.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - ETEC (Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli): ETEC is another type of Escherichia coli bacteria that causes traveler's diarrhea. It produces toxins that act on the intestinal mucosa and cause watery diarrhea by adhering to the intestinal mucosa by fimbriae called colonization factor antigens.

Option B - EIEC (Enteroinvasive Escherichia coli): EIEC is a type of Escherichia coli bacteria that invades and damages the intestinal epithelial cells, leading to an inflammatory response. It can cause dysentery-like symptoms but does not specifically cause effacement and attachment of intestinal cells like EPEC.

Option D - EAEC (Enteroaggregative Escherichia coli): EAEC is a type of Escherichia coli bacteria associated with persistent diarrhea, particularly in young children. It forms aggregative adherence patterns on the surface of intestinal cells but does not cause the effacement and attachment observed in EPEC infections.
